They are one of my favorite things in this world...covered in garlic, butter, spices and Romano, grilled and served with bread...so simple, so delicious, I don't understand why they aren't on the menu everywhere that has oysters. Other things you should know:1. They make a delicious Bloody Mary (with okra!).2. The horseradish is INTENSE, and might make you cry.3. The fried shrimp platter is huge and pretty much perfect. 4. I love you. 5. But that's the ugliest shirt I've ever seen. Throw it away.6. You should round your check up to the nearest dollar to donate to charity.

Reviews.Author: Betty N.
Reviews.Content: **SOLID OYSTERS AND THE WHOLE SHA-BANG**I was lucky, so I didn't wait in line (thanks awesome line waitress).Friendly service and cute place inside.ORDERED:*1 DOZEN CHARGRILLED OYSTERS ($19.49) - Piping hot. Good, but needs to be shared. Too much grease with the cheese.*1/2 DOZEN OYSTERS ($8.75) - Liked these better than the chargrilled. Not too sweet. Need sauce.*2 LBS. BOILED CRAWFISH ($18.98) - Winner! Big, fresh, and tasty. I should have ordered another pound for myself.*1 ABITA AMBER BEER ($4) - Delicious and refreshing with the seafood. A must order.*LARGE ETTOUFEE ($12.99) - Another winner. Taste-wise, unbeatable. Flavorful, rich, and the accompanied rice was perfect.*PECAN COBBLER ($5.99) - Perfect ending to a seafood-filled evening.I enjoyed the seafood here.WILL RETURN and RECOMMEND.

Reviews.Author: Farrah A.
Reviews.Content: This could possibly be a five star joint. But I'll explain later...So, while in town, I text Gretchen P in Houston (a NOLA native) on dining recommendations. Yes, I browsed Yelp, but there is just too much to choose from in this fair city! She suggested Acme Oyster House. Just two blocks from my hotel, it was a definite go.Aw hell. Hold up, y'all. There was a 10-plus person line out the door! Much to my surprise, that excited me. "It must be that good," I thought, because right down yonder was another oyster eatery with no wait. Date wasn't too thrilled, but as the hostess walked down the line, I asked how long the wait was: 15-20 minutes ... "Unless you two want to sit at the bar?" Hell yes. Straight inside and to the bar we went ... waving goodbye and blowing kisses to the poor saps in line (no, I really didn't do that. But I could have).And let me tell ya, the bar is the best place to sit. Plenty of elbow room, lots of TVs showing NO college football classics, hooks under the bar to hang your purse and the two friendliest bartenders/servers you could ask for. Tracy and Amanda (I think those were their names; homeboy with long braids and killer green eyes and a sweet gal who lived in Houston after Katrina and told stories about getting lost on the Beltway. "Houston is too big!" she said.)We ordered a half-dozen of the chargrilled oysters. "You're gonna want the other half," Amanda said. I could tell she wasn't trying to upsell us, just being honest. Oh mah gah. She was right! These oysters come out bubbling with seasoned butter and topped with grated Romano cheese and with slices of French bread to sop up all that juice. I could've easily eaten another dozen of these--including the oyster shell. The fire and herby aroma was burned into those shells... I could have if *someone* didn't stop me. Ya hear? Chargrilled oysters at Acme Oyster House are a must. Being so popular and with the name "Oyster House," I wanted more oyster flavors and varieties to choose from. Like, broiled oysters with spinach, deep fried oysters with buffalo wing sauce, bacon-wrapped fried oysters with jalapeno ranch. But the only thing they had were fresh, fried, shooters or the chargrilled (once again, amazing). That's the only reason why I deducted one star. Other than that, this place--environment, service and food prep deserved five stars.Other dishes I recommend are the gumbo (skip the cup and go for the bowl), fried stuffed crab platter ($13.99) which comes with fries, a slice of French bread and your choice of potato salad, slaw or hush puppies. The potato salad certain tasted homemade, with olives, chunks of boiled egg and red potato skins.   I'll be back to try their crawpuppies and get some more of those chargrilled oysters. And once again. Don't complain about the line. The restaurant is small, but the tables turn fast.And here are some extra notes, taken from their menu:An 18% gratuity will be added to parties of 6 or more. There is a $1.00 service charge on all to go orders.

Reviews.Author: Rodrigo D.
Reviews.Content: This place was amazing! My wife and I loved it. We are traveling with our 2 months and a half old son so we were concerned about the space for the stroller. The staff was very friendly and even though you have to wait for 35 to 40 minutes it is well worth the wait. At first they found us a table that would permit having the stroller at hand. The music and noise levels are just at the right level to have a good conversation yet feel the ambiance of an oyster bar. The charbroiled oysters were amazing following the po boys. Do not miss out in this place when visiting New Orleans!

Reviews.Author: Alexandra S.
Reviews.Content: I've been to Acme twice now and while I'm very glad to have had the experience and had fun both times, I probably won't be running back next time I'm in New Orleans.  It is a cool place however with an old-school ambiance.  Acme first opened in 1910 although has been in it's current location since 1923.Most of the time you do have to wait in line to get in although I've found the line to be pretty fast moving.My main problem with Acme is the way they serve their raw oysters.  And it's really the reason I came here to begin with for raw oysters about which I am an ever-lovin' fool.The oysters are served on a platter with the usual lemon and other accroutrements but most disappointingly, they are not served on top of a mound of shaved ice.  This means the oysters are not as cold as I like them.  This go-round they were almost room temperature and that is not good.Acme does make delicious and very rich char-grilled oysters and I've heard their other menus items are good.  But since I can't get my fix of raw oysters as I like them at this place, I'm going to take a pass next time.It's worth checking this place out once but skip the raw oysters and go for either the char-grilled oysters or something else from their extensive seafood menu.  I recommend sitting at the bar as it's more fun interacting with the other patrons.   And maybe you'll get the same saucy bartender.  A fun fact  about this place is the "Oyster Cam".  Go to their website where you can find the Oyster Cam link and at any given time you can watch to see who's sitting at the bar.   So if you go, be careful about what you're doing and with whom!   ;-))

Reviews.Author: Roland L.
Reviews.Content: If NOLA native Betty N (bettygeek.yelp.com) recommends a visit to the famous ACME Oyster House, then you definitely must make it a point to do so.As part of the NOLA in 12 hours adventure, ACME was supposed to be the first stop but a "45 minute" dinner wait dissuaded Mathew M and me, ultimately landing us at MiLa (which I highly recommend). The following day I made it priority because I wanted to try their amazing Étouffée...and of course, their raw oysters. I arrived 15 minutes prior to opening (they open at 11am) and as you would conclude, a line was already formed. An employee came out to take names and party size but I was ensured to be seated with thee first wave of patrons.As 11am rolled around, doors opened and patrons were given personal seating preference. I opted to dine at the bar where I had a front row seat to all the shucking action.yelp.com/biz_photos/_ab5…What's so impressive was after they took my order, I quickly visited the restroom to wash my hands and by the time I returned my entire order was waiting for me! Oh, and by the way, their staff is very attentive and friendly.Raw Oysters ($8.75 for 1/2 dz or $13.50 for a dz): 5/5yelp.com/biz_photos/_ab5…yelp.com/biz_photos/_ab5…Okay, I'm not much of an oyster fan...and I'll confess I didn't care much for Kumamoto oysters at Providence on Melrose in Los Angeles (yelp.com/biz/providence-…) but these were some truly remarkable oysters! I was served some humongous, soft, sweet oysters that has turned me into a believer. My only regret was ordering a half dozen. I didn't go with ACME's Chargrilled based upon Betty N's recommendation and I'm glad I didn't.Seafood Étouffée ($8.99 for small or $12.99 for large): 5/5yelp.com/biz_photos/_ab5…Yes, this was thee best étouffée in my life and I'm glad I had a large order! ACME's perfectly seasoned roux was so silky and blanketed soft fluffy white rice. The entire dish wasn't piping hot, making it super easy to inhale. If I could have this everyday...I would!I was out the door by 11:20am. A whopping 20 minutes spent in oyster/étouffée heaven. I'll be back for more the next time I'm in NOLA...hopefully for longer than a day. ;)

Reviews.Author: Vanessa R.
Reviews.Content: Their oyster are awesome so good! But I really didn't like their fish or shrimp sandwiches too dry

Reviews.Author: Marti L.
Reviews.Content: OYSTERSAlthough there are plenty of oyster bars around, we were set on Acme. This is the home of the 15 Dozen Club, where Adam Richman from Man vs. Food downed 180 oysters in 60 minutes. Super busy spot. Service was friendly but slow. Decent sized oysters. The raw ones were fresh and salty while the char grilled ones were flavorful. Besides the oysters, the food here was mediocre. The gumbo was watery and bland. The jambalaya was too mushy with overly-diced chicken and sausage.Raw oysters: (yelp.com/biz_photos/_ab5…)Char-grilled oysters: (yelp.com/biz_photos/_ab5…)Gumbo: (yelp.com/biz_photos/_ab5…)Jambalaya: (yelp.com/biz_photos/_ab5…)

Reviews.Author: L M.
Reviews.Content: I'm in love, I don't think I had ever experienced a foodgasm until I went to Acme. I had the shrimp po'boy, hushpuppies, and I also ordered the sampler plate. (Don't judge me. I shared some of it but not all of it). The shrimp was GREAT. It was seasoned and fried to perfection, I have never had shrimp that tasted that good in my life. NEVER. I will always stop by this place when I'm in New Orleans. I can see why people were willing to wait out in the cold. It was fantastic. I didn't care for the Gumbo but I've never been a Gumbo kind of girl. I did however like the RedBeans & Rice as well as the Jambalaya. The hushpuppies were great too although some at my table indicated that theirs weren't cooked all the way through. The fries could have been better, I sampled a few off someones plate (I know the shame) and I was not impressed they were limp and definitely needed somemore love. However their Fish, oh their wonderful and glorious fish. Magnificent. (drools) I loved Acme, and I can't wait to try eat there again. Too bad it takes 14 hours to get there.

Reviews.Author: David M.
Reviews.Content: Had to wait for about half an hour but was worth the wait in my opinion. I got a dozen of the chargrilled oysters as an appetizer and then fried soft-shell crab with fries. The food was fantastic and good price for what you get. With over 1000 reviews, there's really nothing else to add... just go and your stomach will thank you for it (your wallet won't mind either).

Reviews.Author: Bridgette A.
Reviews.Content: This place has a HUGE wait so get there early.  The line can be up to a 2 hour wait.  Their Jimbalaya is really good and so aren't the oysters.  They are huge!  So from personal experience and being a huge oyster fan, I ordered 2 plates but honestly got pretty sick of them after the first plate because of how huge they are.  The baked oysters with Cheese are AMAZING. So I would say try one of each!...Their bloody marys are disgusting though, and I'm obsessed with Bloody Marys!..They use gross mix and don't season it at all with horseradish.  It's worth checking out though.

Reviews.Author: Lady O.
Reviews.Content: Tl; dr version: EARTHWORMS UNDER THE OYSTERS = BARFFull version (as spoken in my inner patois): WHAT FRESH HELL IS THIS?! WHY ARE THE RAW OYSTERS SO HUGE AND BLAND TASTING? Yes, they were fresh (like so fresh, they were still caked with dirt) and still in their 'liqueur', but I've never had oysters that tasted like big rubbery boogers.  There was no minerality, salinity, sweetness, or any of those awesome things I look for in oysters - also, the shucking job sucked AND there was no description as towards the type, beyond being big ass oysters that needed hot sauce and lemon juice just to get them in my gullet.WHY ARE THERE 2 GIANT FUCKING EARTHWORMS CLINGING TO MY OYSTER SHELLS AND WHY ARE THEY MOVING?Maybe next time, I won't squirt lemon juice on them to see if they're alive - they are O.oOH GOD, WHY AM I BARFING AT THE TABLE IN MY NAPKIN? Because there's beer on the table, and you NEVER leave beer alone.WHY DIDN'T I TELL OUR SERVER ABOUT THE WORMS? Fucking boyfriend just shrugged and ate all the oysters while I puked, so there was nothing to send back to the kitchen. Sometimes I hate fucking boyfriend.HOW FUCKING GREEDY CAN I BE IF I DIDN'T GET UP AND LEAVE RIGHT THEN? Pretty damn greedy; after the puking incident, we changed tables and had the broiled oysters and split a 'peacemaker' po-boy. And more beer.WHAT OTHER NASTINESS DID I ENCOUNTER? Surprisingly, none. The broiled dozen was tasty, in a "everything coated in butter, garlic and parm cheese is amazing" way, and the  1/2 fried oyster -  1/2 fried shrimp po'boy was ok because it was fried and filled to the brim, but overpriced.  Beer (Abita, natch) was delicious beer.WHAT THE FUCK IS WRONG WITH ME? I have no idea. Common sense says I shoulda sent the oysters back, but I didn't want to complain.  The broiled oysters and the po'boy slightly redeemed Acme, but I can't imagine coming back and waiting on line for 25 minutes for either.Also- I puked at the sight of wormy oysters. Can't over look that.

Reviews.Author: Mel P.
Reviews.Content: My sister and I went here for a late lunch yesterday and it was super yum! The line wasn't too bad around 2:30 PM, only about 5 groups in front of us.  We decided to sit at the bar instead of waiting longer for a table and had a nice conversation with Steve, the oyster shucker guy.I had the shrimp/oyster po boy and she had an order of the charbroiled oysters and a side sweet potato fries. I've only had a po' boy one other time and I didn't like it, the bread fell apart and the shrimps were tiny and soggy.  I was a little worried about trying it here, but, I'm in NOLA, so I better try it.The bread was firm and lightly toasted, the oysters and shrimps were huge, crunchy and were season very nicely.  My sis really l liked the oysters and said she'll be back to get more while she's working in NOLA. If the line isn't around the corner, WAIT!  I overheard one of the patrons saying that the line gets pretty long, so if you see a few people waiting and you're kinda hungry...then wait for it. It's worth it. =)

Reviews.Author: joe R.
Reviews.Content: Best oysters I've ever had in my life, hands down best. I never knew I loved oysters so much. I will come back to NOLA just for them.

Reviews.Author: David N.
Reviews.Content: Oyster House, what do you get oysters of course!The raw were good and fresh. The baked was eh.  I wasn't impressed it was like oysters rockafeller but tiny oysters and not so amazing cheeses.  When you arrive here no matter what time of the day expect a wait.  However, they have it organized very well.  The line goes out the door and almost around the corner.  A hostess will come out and ask for your party size and name.  She will organize inside as people leave.  Instead of having total chaos by taking names and letting people leave you just stand there until it is your turn.  It took about 30 minutes for a group of 10 which was pretty good.  When we were seated we meet our waiter.  He took all of our orders without a pen or paper.  I was scared but he was dead on with all the drinks and food.  I had the sampler plate which was a sad letdown.  It had sausage, jumbolaya, and gumbo.  The portions were tiny.  So up until this point why 4 stars? My friend didn't finish her shrimp etouffee with crawfish tails.  So I took a few scoops of that.  DAMN! That's where it's at.I had a bad streak of bad ordering on my trip to New Orleans so I don't hold that against the restaurant since the item I tried off a friend was 5 stars.  So overall it all depends on what you order.

Reviews.Author: Nick G.
Reviews.Content: What a disappointment!  This place came highly recommended to me by a local buddy of mine, man did I want to kick him in the nuts afterwards.  Because of the raving review, I invited my friends over here and told them how I had been told that this place was so awesome.  Well it sucked.  I was totally embarrassed to have recommended the place, and we all left (literally) with a bad taste in our mouth.  Seriously, not one of us actually liked our meal.I ordered my usual, a few pounds of boiled Crawfish, they came to me and looked very unimpressive small, and they tasted very strangely of nutmeg or some other wierd spice I wasn't expecting.  Another person ordered their raw oysters, which was a popular choice when looking around at the other tables and certainly looked pretty impressive, but he commented that they were pretty small and nothing special... I'm gonna have to trust his opinion on that one.  Everything else ordered was gross/nasty fried foods, something that looked like it came from a Long John Silvers.  Oh, and to top it off, they had horribly bad service.  We had to flag down a waiter every time we needed something, including our bill.Do not go here!  I think their main clientele are the drunks stumbling over from Bourbon St craving something fried.

Reviews.Author: Jessica S.
Reviews.Content: Yet another place that doesn't need another review by little ole me, but good god, I am still dreaming of those chargrilled oysters. Holy crap. Wow, yes, I think I just salivated.The raw oysters (I gotta use the crackers--no shooters for me) were tasty. And, you know what? Those crawpuppies are like a bite of heaven. Crawfish and hushpuppies together? In one delicious bite? Or two if you bite 'em in half.  Um, okay!!The stuffed crab thing was my least favorite, but we ordered it toward the end, so I was mostly already full from the other bites. Washed it all down with an Abita Wheat and left fat and happy.

Reviews.Author: Francesca L.
Reviews.Content: I'd heard about this place being popular, but we were first in line on this particular Sunday. Whilst wandering around trying to find a nearby place for...breakfast? Ted C, a friend, and I gave up and decided to go ahead and wait for this place to open. We got there at 1045 to find the waitstaff chillin and having their own breakfast. Of course we were starving and looked sadly through the window, yet they took no pity on us, the lone souls waiting for a meal, they waited until 11:00:59 to open the doors.When we finally were seated, the waitstaff was prompt and friendly. Ted and I shared a dozen oysters and they were delish. Super fresh and oh so good. Also had some boo-fries cuz my friend said they sounded similiar to something you can eat in Canada--fries with gravy and cheese. The gravy was waaay to salty, and the cheese was shredded cheddar and barely melted..eh.For my main course I had crawfish etouffee..it was ok, definitely could have used some spice.I also finished off my buddies seafood platter and the shrimp was really good as were the hush puppies--almost as good as Mike Anderson's from the day before, but smaller. Pretty decent place if you know what to order. Not much seating, so be prepared to wait--even if you do get there early :p

Reviews.Author: Tina T.
Reviews.Content: After several stops at various businesses and eateries, my husband was still feening for some raw oysters at Acme Oyster House. The first night we tried, they were closed for a private event and luckily as we walked by last night, there was a relatively short line. We waited about 10 minutes and were seated in the back of a very crowded restaurant. I was not hungry at all, but I was willing to make room for some fried crawfish tails. There was plenty of it to eat and it came on top some French bread (always a fave of mine). With the crawfish tails (which were tender and flavorful) came a remoulade sauce. While I love a good remoulade, the cocktail sauce that came with my husband's oysters did it for me. There was alot of horseradish and it tasted damn good with my fried crawfish tails. Mmm, mmm, mmm, I love a thick horseradishy cocktail sauce. I didn't try anything else but there I noticed a number of things on the menu to my liking since I don't do the whole oyster thing. Vedy nize...

Reviews.Author: WaYnE c.
Reviews.Content: 08/11/2011 - 11:59 amFrom passing-by a couple times day and night, I know there's bouncers/hosts from time-to-time managing the lines for entrance into this popular Seafood stop.  Impeccable timing on my part as I breeze along FQ for some snackables.  No lines, popped right onto another Barstool to see what the Seafood was all about in this Franchise-looking Italian-American feeling Sport-pub surroundings.One of the Bar Staff offered the Menu and poured the Iced Tea($1.99) I requested.  In general, service was friendly timely and my Meal came before I knew it.  He did question my low limit consumption order but I didn't budge but he redeemed by pouring additional Iced Tea until I had to cut him off.  Even poured a Take-out for the SF tourist I met for their onward Journey.------------------------I know I know, I should come back during Oyster season, right?1/2 dozen raw Gulf Oysters($8.75)Plastic Take-out Dipping-Sauce sized Gulf Oysters.Little bit sweetness, more like wateriness.Thin one-bite best with Seafood Horseradish sauce.1/2 dozen Chargrill Gulf Oysters($11.50)The Oyster size became even smaller and easier to overcook.The sauce cheesy garlic herb oiliness nice with soft Bread.Not my favourite variety but good to try once.------------------------My next chair Neighbours visiting from SF quite enjoyed their Po-boys and it seems the couple already planned ahead this day for Lunch AND Dinner here, now that's dedication.  Maybe I should've went with Deep-Fried everything & anything Po-boys that the Non-locals and Locals love so much.

Reviews.Author: Megan S.
Reviews.Content: Mandatory if you come to NOLA. So, you have a discerning palate? Come here. You don't have that much money? Come here. You already have reservations for somewhere else later? Come here. Your sobriety is questionable? Come here. Chargrilled Oysters. In my opinion, you don't really need to try anything else. I can and have eaten a dozen of them, which is embarassing because they're huge, and I'm a small lady (or I was at the time). All people who claim the raw oysters are better, I raise you a plate of these babies. Don't tell me that swallowing a slimy booger with some sauce is better than biting down on one (or 12) of these savory treats. Tips - try their local beer, and throw the hickory Tabasco sauce on the chargrilled oysters, it's speech-impairing good.

Reviews.Author: Peter T.
Reviews.Content: [ Food: 4/5 ]    [ Ambiance: 3.5/5 ]    [ Services: 3.5/5 ]Prices: $$ (average $15/person)Expect to wait in line no matter what time of the day or day of the week. My advise, if you really like the slimy sea creature, then WAIT and be patience!My partner and I decided to spend the weekend in NOLA for our first Mardi Gras celebration. We flew in by 8am and we had the whole day to spend. So, after a 2.5hrs "breakfast" at Cafe du Monde, we decided to have lunch here. It was about 12.30pm on Friday and the line already spilled out on the street, the wait was about 25mins average. NOTE: if you come as a couple and dont mind sitting at first available, then you get in sooner, there was 2 big groups (4 and more) in front of us that had to wait for over 45mins...Anyway, back to the food... We were seated on the bar close to the entrance with 3 staff behind the counter shucking the oysters and serving at the same time. We started with a dozen raw $13.50 and within 5 mins, poof, those things just gone... My partner was not a fan but he actually enjoyed it, so we ended ordering another dozen. The "homemade" cocktail sauce really helps for those who dont like the fishy taste of it. In addition, we had half dozen of the chargrilled oyster $11.50, this is absolutely addictive and divine with lots of butter, garlic and herbs. We even soaked up the juices with the 3 pieces of bread... In addition, we tried a bowl of seafood gumbo $7.49 and a large shrimp ettouffee $12.99. Both were pretty generic and nothing to write about... The hype is true, ACME does serve up some of the best oyster in the city. We tried another place (Oceana Grill) and it just fall flat. So, if you skip the other dishes and just stick to the oysters (especially the raw & chargriled and thats were my 4 stars are given) and some Abita beer, then you are good to go...

Reviews.Author: Liz R.
Reviews.Content: Review #200 reserved for the best chargrilled oysters in life. You'll have to wait in line to get into Acme but it moves fast and the oysters will make it worth your while.Service here is good. Beers are cold. I deducted a star because all the other food is kind of...sucky. Just order shitloads of the oysters and Abita draft. Skip all other food. The boo fries were bleh. The crawfish po'boy, bleh. Rice and sausage, bleh. Bread pudding, mmK. Don't want to wait in line long at all? Hit this place up for lunch.

Reviews.Author: Shanlong Z.
Reviews.Content: What can I say??? Woohoo! The Char grilled Oyster is the best ever! You need try it!BTW, the waiter is not as good as the food...

Reviews.Author: John L. H.
Reviews.Content: There seems to be a lot of Acme haters out there. This is surprising to me since I consider this Acme a must visit for any visitor to our city.Acme may claim to be an oyster house, but they are so much more. Sure you could eat 60 dozen oysters, but who would want to? Oysters are disgusting. Acme has great fried seafood. Try their seafood platter or one of their Po-Boys. The seafood is always fried perfectly and tastes wonderful. Surprisingly, Acme also offers a pretty good roast beef po-boy and red beans and rice. Another one of my favorite dishes is their seafood gumbo. Packed with shrimp and crab, this seafood gumbo is among the better varieties I have tried.Because this is the FQ location, you may have to wait. That's ok. Just get a beer and dream about your meal.As a local, I will usually hit my local Acme, but if you're in the quarter, this is the place for seafood.

Reviews.Author: Vicky L.
Reviews.Content: I have always gone next door to Bourbon House when I want oysters. But since I had a friend from out of town with me, and we all heard such great things, we decided to brave the 45 minute wait outside. I am so disappointed. Fresh oysters: 3/4 of them had sand in them, and the shells were especially dirty. Chargrilled Oysters: averageGumbo: It was ok. fried oysters: pretty good. Boudin Balls: they were ok too. Pimm's Cup: It doesn't exist here. The waitress said that she didn't even know what it was. It is a southern staple; how do you not know what it is? Nothing stood out for me. our waitress was pretty bad. She kept forgetting to refill our drinks. and she also decided to go on a smoke break after we asked her for a drink refill too. I am going to pass on eating here next time. BTW, They are very strict about having your whole group when you are being seated. The group of 8 or so in front of us was missing one person, and they said that they wouldn't seat them unless everyone was there, and would break up the table to seat the people behind them.

Reviews.Author: BRIAN M.
Reviews.Content: Bomb as you know what....

Reviews.Author: michelle k.
Reviews.Content: do you know why they have over 1600 reviews?!?! because it's good. are there alot of tourist here?!?! yes but it's because it's good. and i see locals here too. i normally don't like cooked oysters but grilled oysters in butter?!?! let me get 2 dozens for myself!there was a line but the service is so fast and efficient that i only waited for 15 mins. so worth it. PS don't get the po boys. you can find better somewhere else.

Reviews.Author: Hue K.
Reviews.Content: Three and half stars.My dear Tu-Van guided me to Acme. It was around 5 pm, so we didn't have to wait but there is line of people waiting for a table ALL the time. I don't like oyster but Acme's baked oysters were so delicious. Seafood platter was good for trying different seafood. huge portion and fast service.  Fries are not that spectacular so if you want New Orleans seafood, just go for po boy. Highly recommend the baked oyster though.

Reviews.Author: Maria C.
Reviews.Content: This is what I'm talking about!!!It was cold, wet and rainy as we waited in line for 45 mins for a seat. Well worth the wait! I have to say it was one of my favorite meals in NOLA.  We sat at the bar and our bartender gave us recommendations, gave me a sample of beer and was very attentive to us. Definitely working the busy bar! Ordered:-Abita Purple Haze on draft ($4): Love it paired with my meal. My fave draft that I had in NOLA.-1/2 order of Oysters on the half shell ($6.75): The oysters were pretty good sized. All I needed was lots of lemon. Delicious!!!-1/2 Po Boy (Fried Shrimp) and Gumbo combo ($13.75): This was the first time I had real po boy and gumbo. Unforgettable! I squeezed lemon on my fried shrimp and after 1 bite - YUM! The bread was light and crunchy and not heavy. The gumbo wasn't spicy and had really good flavor. Although it was dismal out, I had a really great dining experience and the food itself made this trip worthwhile.

Reviews.Author: Vince W.
Reviews.Content: This place was good. Nothing too amazing. The char-grilled oysters were the highlight but they were very gritty. I've had better. Good selection of food and nice service. Overall just ok for me.

Reviews.Author: Steph C.
Reviews.Content: Our family is disgusting.  In a single day, we lunched at Willie Mae's and Mother's, snacked at Cafe du Monde, ate full three-course dinners at Commander's Palace, then rolled into Acme Oyster House, deeply satisfied but with room for more.We ordered a dozen raw, half a dozen chargrilled, and two shooters for me and the pops.  A couple of Blue Moons also made their way onto the table.  Despite the crammed status of my stomach, I found the oysters delicious.  I would skip the shooters unless I just wanted to drink - they contained a frightful amount of vodka to still qualify as food.  The raw oysters were great quality, especially for the price, and the chargrilled version doused in garlic butter and grated romano cheese was blissful.  Then again, I think boogers would taste good swamped with butter and cheese.The vibe was very cool, kind of laid-back with a judicious use of neon.  I enjoyed the Wall of Fame displaying the "15 Dozen Club," which I really think I could join if I felt like making myself sick one day.  TV screens showed the World Series of Poker, which is always a plus.  Our waitress was very friendly and didn't seem to care that five of us were occupying precious table space and only ordering a few bites each.  When I told my dad to leave a nice tip, he nearly left a twenty before we pointed out that that was almost 100%.  Good service, good prices, good atmosphere, and good food - Acme may not be pitch-perfect fine dining, but what's not to like?

Reviews.Author: Jeffrey C.
Reviews.Content: It's a NOLA institution. You probably gathered that by the sheer volume of reviews about this place.Ah, the famed Acme Oyster House. Naturally, we came here and didn't get any oysters. We strolled by here a couple times during prime dinner hours, and the line goes out the door and around the corner. Ok, so there's no actual corner, but if one existed, the line would have curved around it. All to say, if you're coming during peak times, prepare to wait.As for us, we came at around 10:30 at night, pre-Bourbon. Thanks to our insane timing, we went straight to the bar with nary a wait. If you're in line though, pick up a drink at nearby Bourbon to pass the time.Our rationale for coming, besides the famousness of it all, was to sample the crawfish. It's still pre-season, but the other French Quarter places we walked past were of comparable price and lackluster quality.The restaurant itself has sort of a grungy feel that makes you feel like you're in a bar setting. True to form, I ordered an Abita, which came complete in a plastic cup. You stay classy, now. The drinks are poured ready to go.Our bartender/waitress was overbearingly nice and a tad bit funny to boot. She was probably the nicest waitstaff we had on the trip (sans the super service at NOLA; coming soon), so kudos to her for that.As for the food, the crawfish was just decent, and pricey at $9.99 per pound. Not faulting them there, it is what it is. I went with neither the oysters nor the crawfish, instead opting for the etouffee. S-M-R-T, huh? Solid flavor, excellent portion.Based on the ambiance, location, service, and history, a solid 4 star joint. But I almost feel like I should grade out an incomplete, since the meal came with nary an oyster. Next trip, folks.

Reviews.Author: Kristen M.
Reviews.Content: My first real southern meal was at Acme Oyster House - noted to be a New Orleans institution (serving Louisiana seafood since 1910).My company had rented out the upstairs balcony for a reception. It was a private room and had a separate entrance from the restaurant downstairs. Yet it was nice to see that there was a long long (LONG!) line down Iberville St. and all I had to do was cut the crowds of people to a semi-VIP event. We had a buffet of all the fixings:*Jambalaya* Seafood Gumbo*Red Rice & Beans*Hush Puppies *Fried Shrimp & Catfish*Mac & Cheese* Sweet potato fries* Grilled smoked sausageand most importantly *OYSTERS*There was a bar that was available and the bartenders were cool and very accommodating to any request. Overall, cool place, great vibe, yummy food in New Orleans!

Reviews.Author: Aria v.
Reviews.Content: New Orleans Birthday Trip = Eating in the French QuarterAcme's an institution. It's got everything you could really want in a fast casual dining experience, but you go for the oysters. You always go for the oysters, even if you don't like them, you eat them, because it's Acme and that's just what you do.Food:Oysters!!! I love them, and how can you not? These big ol' things are plucked outta the water and shucked in what I can only guess to be moments before they're slapped on a tray and served for you. Fresh seafood's always the best and you can't beat this freshness when you're so close to the bayou.To eat oysters: Add lemon, add sauce, slurp, repeat. Drink Abita and order more when you're done, of both.We also got the combo platter of gumbo, jambalaya and red beans and rice. The jambalaya was goooooood, not quite spicy enough but delicious none the less. The gumbo was eh, not so much, and the rice was under cooked while the beans were overdone. I love the oysters, but let's face it, this isn't 5 star dining. Even with the Bourbon St atmosphere (read: borderline drunk and disorderly) institutions should still be given their rightful stars. 3 for you, Acme, you're food rocks, and you'll live long and prosper, but you're still as touristy as they come.Venue:True to form, after drinking at HoB we lined up outside Acme and only had to wait for about 5 minutes before we were called in off the line. Don't let the line wrapping around the block intimidate you, you're going to get in quicker than you think.There's seating for well over 100 here easy, but the goal is to have each table turned over in under 30 minutes, so no dallying. The tables are red and white checkerclothed and the plates are a step above paper, but it's what you came in for, so don't scoff. If you're looking for upscale oysters with little forks and caviar, then go next door to the big gold and leather, white table cloth establishment known as the Bourbon House and get price gouged. But you know, it's your call.

Reviews.Author: Dan G.
Reviews.Content: You gotta suck the head on dat der crawdad!  This is the place to do just that.  Sure, it's a tourist trap.  That was clear when they made us cue up in their roped off line outside and then whisked us inside to seat us at one of the many empty tables.  Seafood is what you want to have here.  Since I wretched like Beetlejuice in the Sternshow bathroom the last time I tried downing oysters here, it would be crawfish for us today.  The crawfish were about $10 a pound and we're good sized.  Twist them where the head joins the body and tear the shell from the sides of the tail.  Squeeze from the bottom and that whole piece of meat should be there for you.  The daring will want to suck the head to enjoy all of the boil seasonings.  Don't gross out, it's really where all the flavor is.  Mix up this feast with a few cold pints of Abita, Andygator for the lady and Turbodog here.  I liked how the server basically laughed at me when I asked if we could take the brews with us.  Round two will be roadies, then.  I also am a big fan of a place that has a sign stating "Self service in the rear"  I'm still in awe of the 15 dozen club of the oyster champions listed on the wall.  My math skills are suspect, but that's a lot of anything.

Reviews.Author: Andy D.
Reviews.Content: As far as food is concerned, top notch, five stars, but I will never come back. There is something about a tourist town, they don't know how to treat tourists, or any one else for that matter, From Key West to Kalamazoo you will find that one person, who must think people who aren't from around "these parts"  are scum, don't tip, git in the way, and / or smell.Well, I don't mind tipping, and I'm always taken back, when I meet the waitress from hell.This dear sweet sweet woman, interjected in everything, from conversations, to when I went to take a Yelp picture of my oysters, she said no photo's are allowed.What a putz, top secret, yeah this place needs to remain a secret, as a matter of fact so secret maybe no one will come. I hate to break it to ACME,  when the cave man learned to smash open the oyster a few years back, the secret was out!Great food, but idiots can turn you off, I can see why she wouldn't want pictures taken of her, who would want one, but an oyster theoretically was uglier then her, that is from the outside.

Reviews.Author: Theresa P.
Reviews.Content: For a place that's firmly on the tourist trail in NOLA, Acme was surprisingly good.  I hate spending my vacation time (and money, and calories) at dining establishments with long lines and souvenir tees.  Usually, they are overpriced and overrated. Not so with Acme. Yes, there was a line, but it moved fast and the staff was friendly.  They could get away with being rude-- thousands of drunk tourists every day would make us all little snippy, but everyone was cheery.The raw oysters were good, but not clean-- a good bit of grit and green goop.  I'm sure that its just a volume problem. They churn them our so fast there's no time to get them purged. Otherwise, obviously a high-quality product.The charbroiled oysters were delish (butter, garlic, cheese-- what's not to love).  Our waitress was superhuman fast and friendly.  Prices are fair, and all varieties of the local brew, Abita, are on tap.  Definitely worth a stop.

Reviews.Author: Garrett P.
Reviews.Content: They have chargrilled oysters. I can't really tell you too much more about these guys, because I got that, some bread, a pour of Sam Adams and I also got annoyed by the loudmouth from Connecticut sitting next to me.How do I know he was from Connecticut? He loudly told me in between massive belly laughs that kept erupting from his face for no good reason.Example: "So, what brought you to New Orleans?"Him: "AAAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA­HAHAHAHAHAHA, vacation."Eating those oysters made putting up with him worth it.These have a little more 'oyster' flavor to them than the ones at Dragos, whereas at Dragos you're getting a bit more filling (more cheese and a touch more seasoning). These guys trump it for the fact that: 1.) You're in a restaurant, not a hotel; and 2.) they're nice here, and the woman at Dragos was just not all that pleasant.

Reviews.Author: Philip L.
Reviews.Content: Quintessential late night New Orleans hangout. Had some battered blue crab claws (good not great) at a bottle of Barq's root beer, and my coworker really liked the raw oysters, which is their signature here.Thsi place is dependable for tourists and locals alike, quick walk from a lot of the main hotels near Canal street.

Reviews.Author: aja h.
Reviews.Content: This did seem a bit on the touristy side but hey bein a tourist I loved it!!~. A dozen oysters on a half shell for about $11...and they weren't small n skimpy at all...me n my pops had like a dozen each. :0) I had the crawfish e-tu-fluffy (what me n my pops etouffee?) n that was oh so super yumm. I never had this dish b4 so I wasn't sure what to expect. But when it came out it looked n smelled great.  It was packed with flavor but  I was expecting spicy :0( so I added in some chipotle Tabasco n that just made it for me. I had the small n that was just enuf :0)

Reviews.Author: Mona M.
Reviews.Content: Oysters. Is there anything they can't do? Well, they can't walk. They can't talk. But damn. They're delicious. And that's good enough for this gal. I like eating them standing up at the oyster bar. Watching these guys shuck is like watching good ballet. It's a dance. Especially when it's busy. As I was on my third dozen, the shucker gave me such a great smile. And a few free oysters. He leaned in. Spoke softly. Said, "I want to marry a woman just like you." Hee.The po-boys are good too. But there's just something about raw oysters that sing to me. Oh, and a nice Dixie beer.

Reviews.Author: Vince E.
Reviews.Content: New Orleans. Beads. Booze. and Oysters! Oysters? That's right so much of this chargrilled seafood, you would hire a New Orleans copper to stand guard at the door for "protection" too. Funny the guy really just hangs around and chats about the Saints!I'm not a huge fan of raw oysters, but these chargrilled half shells are on the money. Get a dozen, better yet get two dozens, you won't be disappointed at all. I think they just throw them on the fire, lace them with butter, cheese and some crack. They will have you coming back for more. This night I also had the chance to try the sampler which is a good intro to gumbo, jumbalaya and beans/rice.Aside from oysters, and gumbo they fry everything else too and make sandwiches out of it. Definitely a stop in.

Reviews.Author: Mariela D.
Reviews.Content: Unless you've been living under a rock, you know that Acme Oyster House is a New Orleans institution - if you visit, you need to get your butt over here for some fresh oysters, hush puppies, shrimp po-boy, crawfish.. and maybe even some fried catfish and slaw. Mmm, mmm.I had a little bit of everything. Their fish batter has secret spices in it (they won't tell you, I tried), giving it a cajun kick that contrasts nicely with their house tartar sauce.And their oysters were SO fresh and SO clean **Outkast plays in background** I normally dont eat oysters because even the slightest fishy taste or grit in the oyster grosses me out. But theirs are served on a bed of ice, and as clean and fresh as they come. I also really liked their gumbo and red beans and rice.Our server even came and sat down with us to chat for a minute. He gave us some tips on what tours to go on and places to visit. What a cool dose of southern hospitality :)You definitely won't leave hungry, unless you're a vegetarian.

Reviews.Author: Jo H.
Reviews.Content: We came in on a Sunday.  The Saints were playing at home, the streets were quiet and we beat the crazy lines that usually snake down the block. We shared a dozen of the Chargrilled Oysters.  They came out sizzling with a cap of golden melted cheese on top.  The oysters were good but the could've been shucked a bit better.  There were definitely traces of shell in a few of mine. Meh...I ordered a bowl of the sea food gumbo.  The base flavor was ok.  The seafood was pretty skimpy mostly shrimp meat with a few shreds of crab.  For the price I'm not sure what I expected.A couple of friends ordered the 1/2 and 1/2 platter to share.  It came with fried fish and fried oysters.  The plate was huge filled to the edge with golden fried goodness.  All four of us ended up having to chip in to finish it.  We didn't mind.We also had the fried crab claws.  They were cute and fun to eat. Especially with beer (Abita Amber) and a game on the big screen. We were so taken with the Chargrilled oysters from Sunday we decided to venture back for another dozen on Monday.  The restaurant was much quieter.  The oysters were cleaned perfectly this time.  I could eat a dozen of these by myself.  We wished for a little more bread for sopping the drippings (I know so bad and I don't care) it's probably for the best that there wasn't more. Avoid the rush hour for oysters and you'll be fine.

Reviews.Author: Chris S.
Reviews.Content: Go during lunch. I walked right in at 11:30 and grabbed a seat at the bar. Half the tables were empty as well, but that was a temporary situation.What will come as no surprise to anyone, I came for the oysters, and they were great. I had a dozen, raw and they were sweet and delicious. On the side, I had some Boo Fries (brown gravy and cheddar cheese-basically poutine, for my friends north of the border) and a Dixie beer. The service was friendly and the beer cold, so all in all, a really good experience.**************************************************­***Update: Definitely go during lunch. I went back and walked right in again a few days after originally posting this. While it was crowded, there was no wait either time.

Reviews.Author: Dora V.
Reviews.Content: They tell you to go to Acme oyster house so you can say you went there.  I went there to go there and tell you I went there.  I went there.  You might want to go there to say that you've been there.  On the other hand, if you see the ludicrously long line outside and feel like bailing, just bail.  You can still say you went there.If you go there, you will find a black and white checked diner-meets-bar.  The oysters were on par with the rest of the countless oysters I enjoyed in New Orleans, while perhaps a little muddier than most.  It's been a tough season for them.The iconic nature of the place is evinced by Manning jerseys and official Saints and LSU paraphernalia, but my favorite part of the decor was the wall of fame for those oyster-eaters enthusiastic enough to have joined the "15 dozen club."  The 15 dozen club, indeed!So I went there, and the most important thing is that I can say I went there.  So there.

Reviews.Author: Paul K.
Reviews.Content: You mean all I have to do is eat fifteen dozen oysters and they're half price?  Plus I get my name on the wall and a hat and tee shirt? No prob. And who needs an hour?  Eighteen minutes is plenty. Then we'll see what else you got.The grilled oysters buck tradition (Romano cheese and seafood don't mix)  but were nonetheless a tasty novelty--the fried seafood picture perfect. Don't mind the line outside, it moves fairly quickly. Unless you're part of a larger party ask for bar seating. Wanna know the score, N'awlins wise? Just ask the shucker.

Reviews.Author: Scott P.
Reviews.Content: Great little place right off Bourbon Street on Iberville. There was a line when we got there at 5pm, but it moved quickly and in a very orderly manner. Good crowd control by the restaurant.I was told they have terrific Char-grilled Oysters, so I decided to go with that for my meal. I started off with a dozen and after tasting them ordered another half dozen. The oysters had a great light smokey flavor to go along with butter, garlic and Parmigiana cheese. The texture was perfect. They may have been the freshest oysters I've ever eaten.  My sister went with Boo Fries which were drenched in a wonderful beef gravy. I sampled those in exchange for a few oysters. We also got an order of hush puppies that were quite authentic. You could tell they were fried in the same oil as the catfish which is exactly how it should be. She finished up with a 10 napkin beef po'boy that was wonderful. More of that delicious gravy on soft bread with beef. Mmm...Messy and tasty. All in all this was one of my favorite food experiences while I was back in New Orleans. Tip. Try to go early, it seemed like the line grew longer the later it got.For good seafood and good cooking all around, y'all should try this place.

Reviews.Author: Vanessa N.
Reviews.Content: Super overrated.  There were a lot of things that left me unsatisfied - mainly the taste of the food.  Things were either too salty or bland.  Adding Tabasco sauce improved the taste immensely, but what a shame to have to add Tabasco sauce to everything.Raw oysters tasted bland.  Gumbo tasted like salt.  I heard the fried oysters tasted funny alone but tasted okay in the po-boy with bread and lettuce. Hush puppies were good, but I would not recommend standing in line for 30-40 minutes for them.  I'm not sure I could recommend standing in line for 30-40 minutes for anything at Acme.Service was okay but Acme is crowded so our server was quite busy that night.  It did take some effort to get a hold of her and she forgot to bring out a beer so she comp'd it for us.  There are oyster/seafood places all around New Orleans.  I don't think that Acme lives up to its hype.

Reviews.Author: Seung Eun C.
Reviews.Content: It's all about the oysters here and I cant see why it shouldnt be less than 5 stars..The raw ones were plump, sweet, briney, and all things oysters should be!  At about $13/dozen, these were SO worth coming here!But, the chargrilled ones were even better! Talk about an explosion of flavor in your mouth.  Make sure to mop up the cheese and oyster sauce on the shell with your bread. I can't comment on the other stuff because we only came for the oysters.This will be my first stop the next time I'm here!

Reviews.Author: Valerie W.
Reviews.Content: Yum! Yum, yum, yum!!!!While I was in New Orleans I had oysters in some capacity at every meal.  Acme were by far the best!The first time we went to Acme we waited on line, which was fine, the line moved quickly.  We were sat at the oyster bar, right under the web-cam.  I, of course, texted all of my friends to check me out, but none were available. :(The oyster shuckers were standing right in front of us, and were friendly and engaging.  They recommended different ways to dress our oysters, talked about life in New Orleans, asked us where we were from, etc.  It was fun to sit and talk with them.Watching the shuckers, you can tell the oysters here are fresh, they just keep shucking and shucking!Along with the oysters, we tried a couple of po'boys, (oyster, soft shell crab, and combo oyster/shrimp.)  The soft shell crab was my favorite.  We also had the boiled crawfish, which was perfectly spicy.Acme has a fun atmosphere, friendly staff, and DELICIOUS food.  It's not the tourist-y place you would expect from seeing the neon sign outside.If you have the chance to be in New Orleans, go!

Reviews.Author: Denise L.
Reviews.Content: One of the best places we ate in New Orleans. Although there was a wait on Saturday at 1:00 PM, the line moved quickly, and our party of 6 was in within 30 minutes. Was seated in the back, and the restaurant is much longer than I had expected. A bit dark and chilly in here. Between the 6 of us, we had about 5 dozen oysters, ALONG with entrees. The oysters were THAT good, and we regretted getting our entrees as the oysters were filling enough. Especially the CHARGRILLED! I've had a variation of it made by a friend back home, but man oh man. Buttery, garlicy, cheesy goodness, all grilled on a fresh oyster! Best part is they give you slices of french bread to dip or douse in the butter left in the shell or on the plate. YUMMMMMM. We were in heaven! I ordered the famous Fried Peace Maker Po Boy, which has fried oysters and fried shrimp and their tabasco infused mayo (we also learned that day that Tabasco is originally from LA! Who knew?). The bread was that french bread goodiness, but I was too full to enjoy it. Also realized I'm not a fan of fried oysters. I expected more, being one of the top 10 sandwiches, but it was just okay. It still tasted good as a leftover though, so that's always a good sign.We also ordered a sign of their Boo Fries. Gravy and cheese smothered fries. I was hesitant, as it sounded like a weird combination, but delicious! The jambalaya was ok, nothing spectacular, and their etoufee was okay too.Service was great, our waitress would even bring refills on our sodas without us asking. We had way too much food though, and our table barely had space for all our food.Definitley order the raw and chargrilled oysters here, and if you're still hungry, the Boo Fries!

Reviews.Author: Tim E.
Reviews.Content: Chargrilled oyster awesomeness. The craw puppies were tasty.  Skip the sweet potato fries - need some brown sugar or something to liven them up.

Reviews.Author: Pity D.
Reviews.Content: 4 stars?! I feel like I'm in a bad episode of the Twilight Zone.ACME sucks. Period. Spent a week in NOLA, ate out every meal and ACME was by far our least favorite. They serve a poor version of Cajun bar food. Jambalaya was decent, gumbo was mediocre and the sausage was the worst I've ever had.Service was not the greatest.  Even for a bar.Save your money and dine elsewhere.

Reviews.Author: Karen S.
Reviews.Content: Been to Acme many times while in New Orleans. I always get the fried shrimp po-boy. Lots of shrimp on the sandwich (it's a BIG sandwich). The cocktail sauce was great - lots of horseradish. I dumped the buffalo tabasco on my poboy - quite good. Husband had the peacemaker (half oyster & half shrimp) and a side of jambalaya, and some of the char-grilled oysters - he loves this place. There is usually a line, but it seems to move quickly. We got better service here than other places in New Orleans - not ideal, but good.

Reviews.Author: Roselle E.
Reviews.Content: Second night in NoLa and I couldn't wait to eat at this place!  There was a line outside when we got there but just so happened that a table for two opened up so we skipped the line and were next up!  We ordered the following:- Fried soft-shell crab- Fried catfish- Fried oysters- Half oyster / Half shrimp po'boy- Oyster shooters- Abita on tap- shot of tequilaall the fried stuff were excellent.  Per the BF, he had better po'boy during lunch at some local spot.  It's noisy in here but I love lively places so if you're looking into having a nice quiet meal, you will not appreciate this place.  Service was stellar.  It's situated right off of Bourbon Street so it's a stone-throw away from all the bars so it was convenient.We left this place happy and satisfied.  Off to the bar we went!!!

Reviews.Author: John L.
Reviews.Content: "Yes my favorite place to be, is not a land called Han-a-lee,Mentally and physically, I wanna be in the New Orleans!" Hmmm, I haven't written a review in a bit, I haven't gone anywhere new in a few, it's a slow one at work........time to dip into the "Archives" Although I haven't been to N'awlins in over a year, I was recently reminded of the good old Acme Oyster House in a recent episode of Man vs. Food and now I have oysters on the brain. And not just any ones, but those big Gulf Coast mammas. Keep in mind this place gets packed during the tourist season (Mardi Gras & Jazz Fest) and plan on waiting a bit. In fact keep in mind that this is a touristy spot. I think the best plan of attack is to arrive with a group, order EVERYTHING, and share. Standouts for me are both the oysters on the 1/2 shell and the grilled one's that have butter and Romano cheese sprinkled on top. You can see a guy out front with a grill making them non-stop, and the smell is off the chain! The po-boys are all good, but the soft-shell crab po-boy is the best. Also of note is the fried shrimp platter. I'd hold off on the gumbo and jambalaya from here, not that it isn't good, but I think you can do better at Mother's, Felix, or Cafe du Monde. Oh how I miss creole, creole, creole. (As I open Kayak and begin looking into early May Jazzfest flights....)

Reviews.Author: Grace P.
Reviews.Content: Are you in New Orleans?Have you been to Acme Oyster House?If yes, great job your mission is accomplished.If not, you better not leave the city without experiencing this gem!Line was out the door, but it went pretty fast for two people. We sat at the bar so we got to see the oyster shuckers shuck the fresh oysters! They were so fresh, the shell was covered with mud.We got the gumbo soup, famous fried lobster/crawfish po'boy, and chargrilled oysters!My mouth is drooling as I type.  Gumbo soup came in a cup and had a perfect blend of seafood and spice.  Ohhh boy was the Po'Boy delicious! Bread was crunchy, sauce electrifying, and fried lobster/crawfish tenderly crunchy! We ordered a dozen of the chargrilled oysters...and I did not want to leave the restaurant.  I know I will never have the same dining experience back at home.  I must go back to new o'leaaanz for this place.WHO DAT!

Reviews.Author: G. C.
Reviews.Content: My husband still talks about this place. When we initially did our research on the French Quarter, the Acme Oyster House continously scored high on all the rating boards. So on our first night we tried to go there for an early dinner. We attempted to patiently stand in the EXTREMELY long line to get in, but we didn't last. We were convinced that no place could possibly be THAT good to warrant such a long line. So we went across the street. Mistake. We made up for it by trying Acme another night and it was totally worth the wait. The size of the raw oysters were enormous. So fresh you could still taste the ocean water. I personally am not an oyster fan, but even I fell in love with their famous chargrilled oysters, which consists of butter, garlic and parmessan goodness. Their crawfish etouffee also delish. Their poor boy sandwich though does not compare to Johnny's. Like I said, my husband still talks about this place. I have truly never seen him eat this much. A full dozen of fresh oysters, a pound of crawfish AND the chargrilled oysters all by himself each time! Yes, that's right. We ended up eating there more than once and we were only there for a long weekend!To this day, the mere mention of NOLA makes my husband groan out loud for Acme!!

Reviews.Author: Michael W.
Reviews.Content: Im pretty sure this was the oyster place we ate and drank at.We had our own private room upstairs in a separate entrance.Great deck view of Iberville St. the hush puppies were yummy and the cheese fries was mmm...to die for!

Reviews.Author: Brandon D.
Reviews.Content: One sentence Yelp review (courtesy of another reviewer):"I would never have guessed that they were oysters if you blindfolded me."On the last day of a recent trip to New Orleans, my girlfriend and I decided we should go and scare up some good oysters in the quarter. I'd tried Desire (another fun oyster place) on a previous, and thought it was decent-good, so I thought we would visit it. Desire was closed, so I suggested we try the nearby Acme Oyster House. I hadn't been there in at least five years, and I thought we'd give it a go. Normally it has terrible lines, but it was bare on Tuesday for lunch, so it seemed to be an opportune moment to check it out.I feel really bad for anybody coming to New Orleans who comes here for a raw oyster and shows up here to find out what all the fuss is about. The oysters I was served at Acme were some of the blandest and least flavorful oysters I've had in recent memory. They came perfectly plated (perhaps *too* perfectly plated?), and seem to have been stored and chilled somewhere in bulk. I looked and looked for any sort of flavor, and the only time these oysters stopped being dull was when one of my girlfriend's ended up tasting like mud, silt, and something that comes out of a body part best left unmentioned on a family review site. It's like this: a good gulf oyster ought to have some sort of taste. Some salt, a little tang, *something*. These were just lumps of flavorless flesh, suitable only for tasting the cocktail sauce they were served with. They were so bland, my girlfriend and I agreed we should go next door to the Bourbon House, and try for a do-over when it came to looking for an oyster.FWIW, here's what I liked about the place:- Expected local beers (Abita variants, etc.) all on tap- Staff seemed nice and friendly- We didn't get sick from the oysters?If you want to understand why I gave this place one star, read the above review, and then realize this place normally has people *standing in a line outside the door* to get in. I think it's just a tourist trap, and if you want good oysters, you should go elsewhere.

Reviews.Author: Karen S.
Reviews.Content: A good sampling of New Orleans fare all under one roof.  For the foodie in search of the "ultimate (po-boy, gumbo, oysters, etc.)" this is not the place, but it's a reasonably good lunch spot (a tad pricey because of the tourist crowd).It's got a buzzing bar-like atmosphere, and can tend to be fairly busy.  Service is inconsistent.I usually get the Shrimp or Oyster Po-Boy, which are good.  Their gumbo poopa is unique (gumbo in a bread bowl), and relatively good.  There's nothing really healthy (and tasty) on the menu; if you are looking for a salad or grilled (not fried) meat or seafood, try elsewhere.

Reviews.Author: Adrian E.
Reviews.Content: Don't laugh at me, but anytime I go out of town, I like to check the Man vs. Food website (TV show on the Travel Channel) to see which places were highlighted in that particular city.  I did see the New Orleans episode and I knew Adam Richman attempted the oyster challenge at Acme.  If it gets Adam's seal of approval, then I have to give it a try!  Trust me, this works out more in my favor than when I followed the TV show Bizarre Foods.  (Note to self: never try the camel brains and fish guts again!)We arrived around 9pm on a Friday and I was starving.  I was initially concerned when I saw a line of people outside waiting to get a table.  Fortunately since there only two of us, the hostess said we could be seated right away if we sat at the bar.  Works for me!  Hungry!  Need food now!  Good luck to those in large groups who want a table.  You might need to plan ahead for that.We were seated at the oyster bar and hanging above I saw the Wall of Fame.  Do I dare try to get my name added?  The all time champ ate 42 1/2 dozen oysters.  Can I top that?  HELL NO!  Maybe I could do 2-3 dozen, but I would be burping oysters for days.  Definitely not a challenge I was willing to accept.  That being said, I was up for one dozen of the fresh, iced oysters just to give them a try.  Overall impression was that they were pretty good, but seemed to have some dirt/grit in a few of them.  I'm not sure how much they were rinsed off beforehand, but I did taste a little of the "shell dirt" in a few.  Good thing I'm not going for the challenge.For my entree I order the Acme "10 Napkin Roast Beef" sandwich.  This was good stuff.  It was indeed messy but it tasted great.  I do have to admit that I only used 7 napkins and not the 10 as advertised, but then again, I try to be a clean eater.  I'd be all over eating this sandwich again on a future visit.My wife went for the Fried Peace Maker Po-Boy which is basically half fried oysters and half fried shrimp.  Given another chance, I think she would have gone for a shrimp only po-boy.  I guess we prefer our oysters raw.I like this place.  This is definitely worth a visit if you are in the area.  Just keep in mind what I said about the wait time.

Reviews.Author: Angela W.
Reviews.Content: I don't give 5 stats very often, but this one probably deserves 6 stars.  ACME oysters has taken me to a whole new place of what fresh oysters should really taste like. First the wait, don't be fooled by this line of people taking over the street, you'd be surprised the line actually moves a lot faster than you think. We arrived around 6PM on a busy Saturday and probably only waited for about 30 mins, which is totally worth it. Once you get settled in your seat. Make sure you order the chargrilled oysters, they are amazing, but it gets better. in my opinion the fresh oysters were the best oysters I've ever had! I think oysters that taste like this is really hard to come by. Everyone should at least try it if they stop by here. Also they probably have one of the best sandwiches I've had anywhere. Loved the oyster in the sandwich so fresh and crisp.

Reviews.Author: Sarabear B.
Reviews.Content: I was never a huge fan of oysters until today.  Acme does it right.  The oysters are fresh, icy cold and huge.  Their grilled oysters are quite a treat.  A half dozen of each and a cup of crab-corn chowder was the perfect meal for me.  I was almost sorry i wasn't hungrier so i could try the Crawfish, the seafood gumbo,  or the Red beans and rice.The service was ok... not the best, but i suspect the large party in the back and the late lunch but too early for the real dinner crowd timing had something to do with that. The quality was exceptional.  I would go back there in a heartbeat.

Reviews.Author: Eric K.
Reviews.Content: I don't know how Acme overcomes its temptation to just throw in the towel...its reputation for seafood, particularly oysters, has already been solidified; its location right off Bourbon Street guarantees that tourists, drunk and sober, will come in for some kind of fried seafood; and it's opened up several other locations in the gulf coast area. Yet somehow when three friends and I showed up at the restaurant purgatory time of 530pm for a quick bite, Acme lived up to the hype. After waiting on line for about 20 minutes, the friendly lady with the clipboard yelled out our name and we entered this legendary restaurant. You really do feel a sense of tradition at Acme--it's divey, wooden, but comfortable, and the focus is still on the food. Since we had dinner reservations in a couple hours, our waiter gave us a confused look after we ordered only a dozen chargrilled oysters and a peacemaker po'boy...we tried to explain our situation but i don't think he understood how the four of us could eat so little. Regardless, our waiter still gave us the time of day and made us feel a little less guilty. But wow, the food made me feel like I was now in New Orleans. The oysters came out on a huge tray, right off the grill, and were piping. The butter and grated romano cheese on top of the oysters created a bubbling, gooey crust that was ridiculously good. While a little gritty, the cheesy oyster paired with some french bread made us grown guys giggle...yes, giggle. Meanwhile, the fried peacemaker po'boy (fried oysters and shrimp in a po'boy) was already cut into 4, and the sandwich was fantastic. The simple combo of fried seafood, lettuce, tomato, pickle, and mayo within the po'boy bread made me wonder why this sandwich couldn't somehow be replicated in New York. Upon leaving, I understood why our waiter gave us a look of disbelief when we ordered. Acme is not a stopping place before the main meal...it is the main meal.

Reviews.Author: Christine N.
Reviews.Content: everyone was RAVING about Acme and it was highly recommended by a native, so i thought i would give this place a try.I had their gumbo...YUM! WOW I have never had gumbo like this before. it was savory with the right amount of spice that i like...like others have said, lines go out the door. Is it worth it...i think so, but only if it's your first time and you're lookin' for a true New Orleans experience. My fiancee ended up getting crawpuppies and an po' boy sandwich...super delicious...The oysters, like I said before, are different. They're a bit meatier, they have a smoother texture, but are more on the sweet side. They're good, but they're different if you're lookin' for a kumamoto or a PNW kind of Oyster.... i'd go and eat oysters all day if I could afford it...I think Felix's across the street is just as good when it comes to oysters, but hey, what do i know? I'm just visitin' from CA. =)

Reviews.Author: Jason C.
Reviews.Content: It's a good place, but not worth the wait. There are tons off great restaurants in NOLA. Don't bother waiting in a line.

Reviews.Author: Joanna C.
Reviews.Content: YUUUUUUUUUUUM. I absolutely loved this place, and recommended it to EVERYONE who asked me where I had the best meal of my visit to New Orleans. I had seen the "Food Heavens - Best Places to Pig Out" special on the travel channel, so I was itching to hit this place up when I arrived for my week long business trip! My coworkers and I waited on the 30 minute line, and were sat pretty quickly at the best seats in the house - at the oyster bar. I ordered a dozen raw oysters, and the guy behind the counter asked if I ever had them grilled. I assured him that I loved it all raw (sushi, steak tartare, oysters - bring 'em on!), and insisted that I get a plate full of the good stuff. They did NOT disappoint. There were AWESOME. So fresh and tasting of the ocean. And the guy brought me a few chargrilled oysters for me to try... and WOW. With melted butter and garlic on toasted french bread. AMAZING. Great service, and I got to eat my fill of oysters. My favorite place in New Orleans!

Reviews.Author: Irene H.
Reviews.Content: A visit to Acme Oyster House is requisite for any oyster lover. Granted, the first time I came here during my 28 hour trip was for jambalaya. My friend wanted jambalaya and we got that along with some gumbo and oyster shooters. The jambalaya and gumbo were good but not out of the world amazing. A tad bit too salty for me. The oyster shooters were strong (maybe we should've mixed them better). After we ate here I met up with Angela C and read her review for the Metairie location... I will jump on her bandwagon and STRONGLY recommend the chargrilled oysters. When my friend and I were perusing the menu, I said "Ew, I don't want to eat cooked oysters" when I saw the chargrilled item. I bite my tongue. As Angela later described to me in person, as I was salivating, the oysters are shucked and placed on the grill in its half shell and then some delicious things are placed on top of the hot oyster, French escargot style (which I also LOVE). The chargrilled comes in 1/2 dozen or a dozen. The 1/2 dozen was more than enough for me...But, that did not stop me from ordering the 'peace maker' fried shrimp and oyster po boy. This was my last stop before the airport and I needed to maximize my NOLA food intake. The peacemaker is huge. Angela and I shared one. Its hefty height makes eating messy. I like the tabasco-infused mayo and the oysters here are so fat and juicy! Also recommend. Don't come here if you're looking for something healthy. A lady sat next to me and asked the bartender if they had steamed veggies or salad. "Is cole slaw salad?"I will mention that the two times I came here during the late weekend afternoons, I went straight for the bar. We had excellent and friendly service from the bartenders. The second time I came, I thought I'd arrived just in time - they had a employee holiday party starting at 5pm, but they continued to seat people through 4:40pm ;)This is a great place for a good, cheap bite.

Reviews.Author: Daniel B.
Reviews.Content: I had the biggest, fattest, freshest, juiciest oysters ever at Acme yesterday (see attached photos to see the plumpness I'm referring to).  I forgot to ask the server where the restaurant gets their oysters from because surely it can't be the Gulf with Louisiana still dealing with the aftermath of the oil spill.  A dozen fresh raw and iced oysters here are $13.50 served with a few lemon slices and cocktail sauce.  The oysters were delicious and I should have ordered more.  Instead, I tried a cup of their chicken and andouille (Cajun) sausage gumbo.  The bowl came out piping hot and the meat was tender and savory.  One of my friends ordered their world-famous "Peacemaker" po' boys, which is a giant po' boy with fried shrimp and oysters.  It looked awesome.Acme is located just off Bourbon St, closer to the Canal side.  It's very popular with tourists, but for good reason (as stated above).  If you decide to visit, come early to avoid any long lines.  They do not take reservations and the lines start forming outside on the sidewalk.  The restaurant gets really busy so service can be spotty.  Acme is a casual eatery, divided into two main sections, and also has a bar and TVs.  They have an oyster-eating competition as well.  If you can finish 15 dozen raw oysters in one sitting, you get a plaque of your name on the wall.  Nice.

Reviews.Author: Sonny S.
Reviews.Content: I knew this place was going to be good after seeing how long the lines were. With that being said, I'm so glad that I waited! The food was absolutely delicious. Here's what I got:-seafood gumbo (amazing with chunks of seafood and andouille sausage)-peacemaker poboy (delicately fried oyster and tender gulf shrimp with a spicy tabasco remolaude)This service was a bit slow which is expected because of how packed the place was, but overall great experience!

Reviews.Author: Maurice Desi F.
Reviews.Content: This place is incredible! My lady and I were seated at the bar (which I highly recommend for out of towners). It was suggested by us to try the oysters there so we got a half dozen raw and half dozen chargrilled. The raw ones were really good...but them chargrilled ones were like something I've never had before. I mean EXTREMELY tasty. I was also told that the hurricanes there were pretty good. And they did not disappoint! I also was intrigued to try the fried peace maker po'boy! That thang right there was an explosion of great flavors all on my tastebuds. The only reason this palce didn't get that 5th star from me....THAT DAMN LINE!!!!!!!!!!Granted, you're gonna have a long wait in line when the food is that good at a place. So that just came with the territory. But if you can wait it out, I assure you that it'll be worth the wait!

Reviews.Author: Pinky T.
Reviews.Content: This was exactly what I was looking for out of a New Orleans feast.Great food, reasonable prices, incredibly fast service.I'd return and bring my friends.

Reviews.Author: Melissa D.
Reviews.Content: I can check this off my bucket list and I was so happy that everything that I heard about this place was true.  Service, food, oysters and the choices of hot sauces made me giggle with delight.  We went there on a Sunday and got their at about 11am to open up at 11:30am and we were about the 4 group in line.  Thank god we got there that early.  By the time the restaurant opened up- the line went down the street and wrapped around the corner!I love the that they have a huge mirror hanging  from the bar to show the shuckers shucking away at the piles of oysters they had on ice.  Then they have their famous wall of fame of the people who triumphed in eating vast amounts of oysters.  Of course, started off with a dozen oysters all to myself and they had mountain dew!  I don't know what Boston Restaurant serves Mt. Dew!  there were 4 different kinds of hot sauce at the table and tried them all.  The oysters were huge, fresh and amazing!   Salty, fresh and buttery.  I had the soft shell crab po-boy which was good.  lightly battered so you can taste the crab itself.  Good size crab and they load on the fries.  good thing was they did not overdo with the lettuce, tomato and mayo.  Thank you, Acme Oyster and I hope to visit you again and have 2 dozen more oysters

Reviews.Author: Jason L.
Reviews.Content: I'm not going to say anything different from most reviews here.  The char-broiled oysters are fantastic.  I had the half shrimp and oyster po-boy with tabasco infused mayo, fantastic.  My GF had the roast beef po-boy and red beans and rice, she was a big fan.  Bread pudding for dessert, awesome.  It had a hot caramel sauce on top. Damn good.We found this on Yelp while in town for one night.  Thanks Yelp.

Reviews.Author: Paul C.
Reviews.Content: people told me this place was touristy and overrated. to them i say, shut up.people tell me that the wait was long and the area outside where you wait smells like shit. to them i say....yeah, sounds about right.but hey, it's nola - its right on the intersection of bourbon street and french quarter, so what do you expect?is it worth the wait? ABSOLUTELY. does it make it better that you can grab a PBR/Coors Light/Enter cheap beer you secretly drank as a minor that you stole from your parents that you thought they never knew about. (they knew about it.)Yes.This is what I have to say, and admittedly I'm a neophyte midwestern, new york transplant with little experience with great oysters. But I can honestly say these were the best oysters i have had in my life.The raw fresh ones, were the largest portions I have ever seen but did not sacrifice in quality or flavor.But the true star of the show, the thing that I honestly remember the most about the food in nawlins - is the chargrilled oysters. something about that deep chargrilled taste that makes you feel like a man (although there may be other factors that go into play), perfectly paired with butter and parmesan, is like an explosion in the mouth, and always keeps you wanting more.The other standouts were the shrimp etoufee (great texture, creamy, fresh, yeah just try it) and the bread pudding (small portion, but wow). my only regret is that my review can't do it justice, but yeah, worth the wait in the end of june when it gets stupid hot, but at least you don't have to deal with the mardi gras crowd...i think that's a good thing ;)

Reviews.Author: Dave C.
Reviews.Content: Service - There was a long line to get in but since there was only 2 of us and we were willing to sit at the bar, we were seated within 5 min. They were fast to take our order.Staff - Friendly & Loud.... Lol. Not a bad thing but the whole place is VERY loud. We had to shout to talk to each other.Food - Mixed results. The chargrilled oysters were good. Not phenomenal, but good. The fried oyster and shrimp po-boy was unfortunately not that good. My wife's "7 napkin beef sandwich" was good.Recommend - Yes, at least for the experience and oyster appetizers. Don't expect a "knock off your socks" kinda food though.

Reviews.Author: Nickie G.
