Reviews.Content: It is so weird that I have been to New Orleans quite a few times and never been to this place.  I can only imagine it is because I would see the line and pass it by for something else.  However, as luck would have it our friends were in line and changed the number of the party to "5" while we were walking over so by the time we got there we were immediately seated.  Score!  Sorry suckers in line!So this place is absolute mayhem.  It was about noon on a Saturday and the line was down the sidewalk, people were shoved into the room in tables that had barely enough room to hold all your food and drinks.  Other people were eating at the bar.  TVs were showing football games and the Saints pre-game show.I wasn't really feeling the oysters on the half shell even though I know I should have tried them.  Instead I ordered a cup of gumbo and the 1/2 and 1/2 fried catfish and oysters meal.  When it came out it was on a small plate that could barely hold all the food so it was piled upwards on the plate.  Catfish filets laid on top of the fried oysters, which lay on top of fries and some bread.  A lemon was underneath there somewhere too.  The fries were so non-descript I didn't eat them, the catfish was good, and the fried oysters were heavenly.  Really, they were ah-maaa-zing.  The gumbo was nothing special, but the warmth hit the spot.  Even though it didn't seem like a very big plate, this was a lot of food and I had a hard time even putting a dent in this.  But I tried damn it, I tried.Service was friendly but soooooo S     L     O     W    !  I guess because it was busy or because the waitress had too many tables?  I didn't get my gumbo initially and when I asked about it I was going to just tell her to take it off as I was already stuffed but she finally appeared with it.  Drinks were empty for long periods of time and new drinks were brought without old ones being cleared away.  The table was way too small for all that.  But it seemed like this was kind of how the service was everywhere, so perhaps I just expect too much?  Side note: if you come here with a group and everyone wants to pay separately then you better bring cash because they will only run two credit cards max for each group.  So our group of 5 had to scrounge cash together to pay.Other than the food I really liked when my girl Megan M texted me to ask if I was at ACME still because she was looking me up on their webcam.  The webcam updates every 2 minutes on their website.  So in an effort to have a good show for her, I smiled at the camera for 2 minutes until it refreshed.  Added bonus - people walking in the door thought I was smiling at them and it made them seem to get more festive as they smiled back.  And I got a screen shot sent to me of my goofy grin later.  Fun times!Next time I come back I'm going to skip everything other than oysters and just eat that - fried and also on the half shell.  They are known for their oysters and I'm just not going to deviate from that tried and true formula.

Reviews.Author: Karol M.
Reviews.Content: We hit this place on a weeknight with a local friend and our kids in tow.  We got there around 6pm & there was a line down the sidewalk, with a doorman.  It didn't take long to be seated, however, and we scored a table next to the bar.  Since it's located in the Quarter, even waiting on line was a little interesting, due to the people watching.My husband & his local friend ordered the chargrilled oysters & by their enjoyment, made them seem like the best they'd ever eaten.  I ordered the seafood gumbo & it also was delicious.  The kids each had a po-boy & were pleased enough to eat it all (which is saying a lot for kids eating unfamiliar food in an unfamiliar place).The prices seem a bit high (probably due to the demand) and the service was pretty rushed (definitely due to the crowd), but this was my favorite restaurant we visited over our three-day stay.

Reviews.Author: Matt S.
Reviews.Content: We ended up a tour of NOLA on Iberville Street so we decided to wait in line for 2 seats at the Acme Oyster House. We were not disappointed. We sat at the bar for lunch right in front of our new friend, Norman, who was schucking oysters continuosly. A very nice man, I might add. We tried a few Bloody Marys and ordered the raw oysters and chargrilled oysters. The raw oysters were cold and delicious. They were gone in 5 minutes or less. Then we shifted our attention to the chargrilled oysters. I was expecting them to be like clams on the grill with butter on the side. Nope, they were grilled on the half shell with butter, seasonings and some melted cheese and they were nothing like I have ever had before. Awesome!!!Then my wife had half a fish Po' Boy and a cup of Gumbo and I had a sampling of their Gumbo, Grilled Sausage, Jambalaya, and red beans and rice. The food was very very good. It is a very cool place to sample some of the cuisines found only in NOLA. You can never find a restaurant like Acme Oyster House except in New Orleans.Very glad we went. We have been running into celebrities just about everywhere. Super Bowl Champion Antonio Freeman was sucking down oysters at the bar with us having a great time...

Reviews.Author: Cameron M.
Reviews.Content: First off when you're going to hit up the Oyster house is to get there before the line forms out front. You might found a line of 30-50 people or you might get to walk right in and sit down.My cousin & uncle and I went here and got luck that group of 30 decide to leave since the wait was too long. That made us the next up in line. We got to sit at the bar and have Pam serve us all night. What a treat it was for us to get a nice fun server/bar gal. We started off with cooked oysters in the shell with cheese of them. These went down so quickly it wasn't even funny. All I remember is that the shells were really hot on my fingers. I had the poboy with oysters for my main dish, I can say that I loved it. I had a beer, hurricane, whiskey to drink all from Pam's choice. She nailed it on the head. Will be going back next time I'm down here!

Reviews.Author: Luke H.
Reviews.Content: Worth the Price. Worth Checking it Off Your List. Worth Comparing it to Other Places.This is one of those restaurants that you need to experience in order to understand New Orleans. Is it a tourist trap? Yes. Is the wait too long? Yes. Is it over hyped? Yes. Is it amazing? Yes.

Reviews.Author: Harry P.
Reviews.Content: Started off my meals in New Orleans here and it was a great way to kick it off.We hit the place early at around 730 and were seated almost immediately. The place is very uniquely decorated with lots of mirrors and black and white. It's a very relaxed place where you can dig into some oysters and sloppy po boys and fit right in.We had some grilled oysters. My first time for it, what a genius dish for people who don't go raw. The oysters still tasted like oysters and the cheese and butter go down nicely with an Abita. I shared a sloppy roast beef 10 napkin sandwich with a friend. It was pretty delish. I'd recommend adding some hot sauce. The jambalay and gumbo were alright. The Peacemaker po boy will also take care of your fried oyster and shrimp needs in one shot. Our waiter was friendly and attentive. Someone thought he looked like LL Cool J.Can't go wrong here. Go in as you are and leave satisfied. It was pretty cheap for New Orleans French Quarter.

Reviews.Author: Edi B.
Reviews.Content: The chargrilled oysters are a must. They are perfectly cooked and seasoned. The butter is too die for. Too bad they only give you like 3 small pieces of bread. I would've eaten a whole loaf of French bread soaked in that delicious butter.

Reviews.Author: Gloria H.
Reviews.Content: We made it in without a wait!  What is the trick - come during mid afternoon after the lunch rush but before the dinner crowds.We were not hungry but seeing there was no line, we had to go in - there's always room for oysters, right?  We sat at the oyster bar and it was a lot of fun chatting with the guys shucking oysters.  What we had:Blue Moon draft - $4.5Sam Adams - $42 dozen of oysters - $27LOVE New Orleans!

Reviews.Author: Marc G.
Reviews.Content: Acme was my first meal in New Orleans and one worth remembering.  When I arrived in the city, it was pouring rain.  I am from Phoenix so heavy rain is a rare and exotic site.  Acme did not have any tables available so we sat at the rawbar, which I would recommend.  We had our orders taken promptly.  The oysters are chucked right in front at the rawbar and sent in bar for frying.  The ice tea that I ordered actually tasted like tea (unlike most establishments in the middle of the country that taste like brown water).  The tea was so good you actually taste the vitamins!The meal arrived in about 15 minutes.  I ordered the oyster and fresh fish plate.  It was lightly battered with a butter and milk fried coating.  Delicious.  The fish was fresh and could not have tasted better.  It came with cole slaw and hush puppies.  The meal was sizable and I was hungry - an ideal situation.I even ventured to have the bread pudding.  Do not miss desert here and come hungry!

Reviews.Author: Trisha S.
Reviews.Content: We ordered the chargrilled oysters..... They were yummy!!! I ordered the New Orleans medley which was a decent amount of food. I wanted to sample a little of everything so it worked out perfect. My favorite item of the sampler is the jambalaya. My husband ordered a crawfish tail PO boy which was also good. Wait time was quick, service was good, and prices were reasonable! I'd go again!!!

Reviews.Author: Sonia C.
Reviews.Content: I knew I had to come here after seeing Adam Richman slurp down 15 dozen of their oysters.  Glad I did!  I liked the place much better than Deanie's.  To be honest, I liked this place so much that I came here again for a pure oyster lunch 3 days later.  The fresh oysters are the same level of briny perfection, but the cooked food at Acme's is much better.We started with a dozen raw and a dozen grilled.  I agree that the grilled oysters are pretty amazing (especially with a dash of the chipotle Tabasco), but in my book, oysters are best raw.  I'm a substantial eater, my head hurts when I think about how the leader of the Acme Oyster eating club put away 42.5 dozen in an hour.We then moved onto the New Orleans Medley (seafood gumbo, jambalaya, red beans & rice, smoked sausage) and found it pretty tasty.  The gumbo was especially good.  Not quite full, we ordered a Peace Maker po boy.  The fried shrimp and oysters made the sandwich good, but the Tabasco-infused mayo made it excellent.  I thought there was an slight bias towards the shrimp in the mix, but that could just be my love for oysters speaking!Though stuffed, I couldn't pass up an opportunity to try their Max's banana foster pie.  Drizzled with caramel, it had a cheesecake-like creamy consistency, though taste-wise it lacked the tartness of cream cheese.  I thought it was really good, but was disappointed when I saw the store-bought Hershey's caramel syrup on the counter by the kitchen.  Oh well.Waits are ridiculously long on weekends, and you have to line up outside so you can't even sit at the bar while waiting.  If you come for lunch on a weekday though, you can waltz right in and have your pick of tables.  Delicious.

Reviews.Author: Joanna M.
Reviews.Content: Where does an oyster go for a drink?An oyster bar!Acme's the place to go for beer, oysters, lightning fast shucking, and all the abita beers available.Sitting at the counter is a necessity.  Best views of the heaps of oysters, shuckers and their humor, and whatever game is on TV, unless it's a Saints game, because there's no way that you could stay on a stool with a crazed hoard of Saints fans in a bar.Just order oysters on the halfshell, an Abita seasonal ale, a side of red beans and you'll be set for your pre-party.

Reviews.Author: Louis R.
Reviews.Content: A. I can throw down oysters B. This spot was the apex of oyster spotsC. Had 36 oysters in like 5 minutes, and ordered 36 moreD. I even had the soft-shelled crab just as a chaserE. I've had tons of raw bar fare from the north east and this spot smokes all of them, no jokeI will hit it again, twice in one day if there is real estate in my GI tract.

Reviews.Author: Stephanie C.
Reviews.Content: This review is going to be mainly 3/4ths about the friggen chargriled oysters. Don't you dare get the raw - don't. you. dare. Chargrilled oysters- would have gotten the whole dozen but I had already ordered the crawfish po boy (damn! haha).  Got the half dozen - a half dozen in heaven it was.  I don't know how they do it- but the oysters are fresh, big and juicy (as a note, I must say that the oysters don't here aren't AS good raw as those in the Northeast- really because they're too big and slurpy- not dainty and delicate like the kumamoto oysters).  Perfectly grilled, perfectly baked- there was a really well done outside shell, housing a creamy oyster inside.  Only down side?  Oysters are gritty down here-- but oysters are sandy in NOLA in general for some reason.A secret no one tells you. Don't eat them with the regular Tabasco, eat them with the Chipotle-regular has too much vinegar. Onto the other (unimportant) stuff....haha just kidding.  The crawfish po boy. It was okay- it was good. Mother's oyster was a big better mainly because the bread wasn't as dry.  We also got the red rice and beans with sausage-- rice and beans good; not TOO mushy, beans still had good texture and the sausage was delicious.  The only bad thing here is that the sausage tasted...hmm...spammy?  But it was great in flavor. Other tips: Come before noon and avoid the line.  And get a dozen of the chargrilled oysters- or TWO.

Reviews.Author: Phill C.
Reviews.Content: I've never seen oysters this big in my life!  So fresh and MEATY.I saw this place on Man vs. Food and had to try the challenge, since we were heading to the French Quarter anyways.  I mean I love oysters and I can eat for hours at an all-you-can-eat korean bbq, so how tough could this be?  As I sat at the counter and the oyster shucking began, I thought becoming an honorary member of the 15-dozen club would be a piece of cake.  I was sooo wrong.150 oysters in 30 minutes... no problem.  Signing a waiver that they are not responsible for my well being... uhm okay.  The eating began and in about 8 minutes I flew through 47 oysters without a problem (well actually I started to slow down at the 40 oyster mark).  The 48th oyster took me about 10 minutes to get down.  Bring it up to my mouth, then setting it back down, then trying again.  I wasn't even full at that point, but the meaty oysters were making me feel very very nauseous.  At that point I had to tap out and couldn't stomach any more food.  Sadly I couldn't try any of those chargrilled oysters topped with seasoned butter and grated romano cheese (argh).

Reviews.Author: Maria M.
Reviews.Content: I had my first oyster experience here, and it seriously changed my life! My girlfriends and I hesitantly ordered a half order of chargrilled oysters to try before placing our order. Once having one bite, I knew what I wanted as my main course and my girlfriends felt the same way. More chargrilled oysters! So we ordered two dozen to share, with some appetizers including crunchy, flavorful catfish tails.  Goodness, it was all so delicious!!The oysters arrived sizzling with a plate of chewy bread.   The oysters were deliciously seasoned with rich spices and cheese.  The oysters were so delicious that we all just had to sop up all juices, regardless of where spotted.  Of course being a group of five, we needed extra bread. Several times. But that wasn't a problem with our waiter.Initially some of my friends were deterred by the line, but as a foodie living in NYC, I don't mind waiting for good food. The line looked long, but moved fast. Just writing this review has got me salivating! This place is a must go for all seafood lovers!

Reviews.Author: Gregg M.
Reviews.Content: No sooner had I landed in New Orleans and dropped my bags in my hotel room, I made my way to the French Quarter and Acme Oyster House.  Yes, it's a touristy joint that probably no self-respecting local in search of oysters ever steps foot in.  However, for a tourist, Acme is kind of like the Café du Monde equivalent for bivalve mollusks.  i ordered a dozen raw oysters and an Abita Amber...and my weekend in the Big Easy was on!  In comparison to some of the other places where I consumed oysters this weekend, Acme's were a bit smaller and, perhaps, a bit more expensive given their relative size.  There were fresh, flavorful, with a touch of brineyness and served properly cold.  Still, I think the biggest appeal of this otherwise unremarkable establishment are the convivial oyster shuckers.  "Stormin'" Norman was a shucking machine...and not just  oysters!  He was a colorful character that was definitely an entertainer just as much as a food server/bartender.Bottom-line:  I checked the block for Acme Oyster House.  I enjoyed it, but there are other, better places for oysters (and food in general) than Acme.

Reviews.Author: Jamie W.
Reviews.Content: Two words... Boo Fries!When I saw these delicious morsels on the menu I knew I had to order them... and of course - return a couple days later for a second plate. Yum! If you've ever been to Canada they're a slightly less awesome version of poutine. Yup, sounds like a dirty word but poutine is bomb!Anyway, we went at odd times and never had to wait in line. Also, if you're in a rush, just saddle up to the bar and order. You can watch the guys shuck oysters to get a real feel for the place. Great service. Friendly bar staff. Fresh as can be oysters. Acme is definitely a New Orleans institution. If you haven't been, you're missing out!

Reviews.Author: Judy F.
Reviews.Content: WORD, the line to get in is deceiving.  Turned out to be a 30 or 40 minute wait.  The food is worth the wait.  The staff is super courteous.  I watched & heard this female staff tell some pompous males who walked straight to the entrance that they have to wait on the line.Got to our table and was greeted by more courteous waiters asking if we want beverages.  A few of us asked the same question:  what kind of beers do you have?  Waiter was patient and repeated herself to each of us (up'ed her volume in the noisy dining area).  Service is good.  To eat:Chargrilled oysters, appetizer - for me, I rarely eat oysters. If you can and enjoy eating shellfish, you must order this.  You can even watch the Grill Master make this appetizer.  Raw oyster cooked on top of a grill, ladles butter on top and sprinkles with parmesan cheese.  AMAZING, cooked perfectly, light on the parmesan cheese and light butter taste.  New Orleans Medley, appetizer - I ordered this as my entree.  I love appetizers b/c of portion and the opportunity to try several menu items in one visit.  My quattro included:  chicken/andouille gumbo, jambalaya, red beans & rice, and grilled smoked sausage (chicken).  I found the gumbo bland, the jambalaya had a slight spicy kick, red beans & rice was full of flavor and the smoked sausage a bit salty.  With every bite of sausage, I would follow it with a spoonful of gumbo.  Still, my kind of eats; I'd order this again.Hush puppies, sides - was okay.  I think it's cornmeal crusted.  I wish it was served with maple butter.The finale - bread pudding w/ whiskey sauce, dessert - this is to-die-for.  I LOVE bread pudding and this recipe is uhh-mazing.  The sauce is sweet like candy.  I want MORE.The bathroom is located towards the back of the main dining area.  Dining area was dimly lite, almost like a pub feel.

Reviews.Author: Beverly A.
Reviews.Content: Believe what everyone says about the line, it's deceiving!  We were told it'd be a 20 minute wait, we waited for 40 minutes.  Was it worth it?  HECK YES!  If the wait were longer it probably wouldn't have been and I would've just been a hungry/grumpy hippo.Here's what we had:- Raw oysters: They're HUGE and meaty!  Totally worth the price!  I've never seen oysters as big as these, but it makes me wonder if other places here have the same size too? - Char-grilled oysters (aka rockefeller oysters): yum yum in my tum!  I can barely eat oysters (i always stick to the small ones because they're sweeter) but I was able to chow down 2 of these easily!- Seafood gumbo: It's topped with a little bit of white rice and cheese.. SUPER good and probably one of the better ones I've had. - Crawfish tails: Deep fried pieces placed on top of two pieces of bread.  It's a good appetizer portion, but was perfect for me since I dipped some into my gumbo, and had oysters on the side as well.  They also have a couple deep fried plates to choose from as well, but you can honestly get those anywhere else (as well as the po-boys) so I'd recommend trying their oysters, if not raw then the char-grilled ones for sure!

Reviews.Author: Natalie C.
Reviews.Content: The long line out the door almost persuaded my friend and I to try and find another spot for dinner - but we decided to wait and see what all the hype was about.  I am so glad we took the risk, since we ended up only waiting 15 minutes (grabbed a couple seats at the bar) and because the food was AMAZING!Tip: get a dozen of the char-grilled oysters if you are sharing with a friend - 3 each would definitely not be enough of the tasty morsels.

Reviews.Author: Kristin M.
Reviews.Content: Everyone talks about Acme.  The line is always loooong.  So naturally, we had to check it out.  And it was...fine.With oyster in the name, you expect the best.  The chargrilled oysters were good, just not as good as Felix across the street.  They were nice and cheesy, but very greasy.  I had the roast beef po' boy because it had the fan favorite star beside it.  It was good, but didn't blow me away.  The gumbo was apparently not great.While everything tasted good, I would never wait forever in that line when I know how great Felix is across the street, which never has a line.  If you insist on going, go early or late.  We arrived 10 minutes before they cut off seating and only waited 15 minutes.

Reviews.Author: Jana P.
Reviews.Content: Nom nom nom nom :) This place has really great oysters. Even my mouth is watering just thinking about Acme Oyster House. Like what everyone says, there is a line all the time to get in to this place but the wait is very rewarding. Once you try oysters rockafeller, you know the wait was worth it. I have been here a couple of times with my friends and hubby. On the 2nd time, my hubby (who does not like oysters at ALL...) tried it and he really likes it. I think that has to count for something. LOL. Great food and friendly staff.A girlfriend of mine told me that Acme Oyster house just opened up another restaurant in Baton Rouge, LA. I must try that place too. Hehe...

Reviews.Author: Tiffie L.
Reviews.Content: 3.5 stars -- My friends and I decided to check out Acme after we heard about the amazing Chargrilled Oysters. We figured we could not leave New Orleans without trying it! There was a 20 minute wait, but this was much better than we expected. Once seated, we put in our order rather quickly (we browsed the menu while waiting): 1/2 dozen chargrilled oysters, the New Orleans Medley appetizer, and the 1/2 & 1/2 Platter (catfish & shrimp) with hush puppies and sweet potato fries. The oysters were really good; I am not a huge fan of oysters, so I am sure I would have liked it more if I did... but yes, it was cheesy and buttery as advertised. The Medley appetizer was a sampler of the gumbo, jambalaya, red beans & rice, and grilled smoked sausage. Each portion, of course, was quite small. I thought the appetizer was good, but not great. The best part was the fried catfish, which was fresh and tender and so juicy! I really enjoy a good white fish. But again, the entree was rather small given the price. Overall, I felt that we paid more than we got... but am glad we gave it a shot. And yes, for oyster lovers, it is a must to try to Chargrilled Oysters!

Reviews.Author: Emily M.
Reviews.Content: If you like waiting in a long line to eat at an overpriced tourist trap with average food, go to Acme Oyster House!Perhaps my expectations were to high (ok, they most definitely were) but Acme was a let down. I have a natural aversion to things named Acme, because to me, the word Acme is synonymous with generic. Acme Oyster House did nothing to change my mind about this. While the dining experience at Acme was by no means bad, it made me question why it is such a popular spot. The raw oysters were good, but the po-boys were average. You can get a po-boy like this anywhere in the country. The service was terrible, because of this I had to give Acme two stars instead of three. Split check tip: they only allow splitting the tab onto three cards.

Reviews.Author: Mike D.
Reviews.Content: The grilled oysters were great and would definitely recommend if you are coming to eat here, but if you want raw oysters and you have eaten good ones in the past, then you will be disappointed.  Their oysters are just plain and flavorless, compared to the ones you can get in New England and in other places.  Their sandwiches and Jambalaya were also disappointing but edible.  If you are a foodie and have already experienced interesting and unique flavors, you will be disappointed by the food you will find in here, but the average eater will enjoy it much more that we did.

Reviews.Author: Austin J.
Reviews.Content: Excellent New Orleans style sea food!  We had oysters in the half shell, gumbo, and sausage, and it was all fantastic.The atmosphere is a bit raucous, creating a very casual experience.

Reviews.Author: Howard R.
Reviews.Content: Char grilled oysters, oyster and shrimp PO-boy, and bloody Mary were all excellent.  Service was great too.

Reviews.Author: samanta v.
Reviews.Content: The hurricanes are horrible.  Like, really really, really bad.The oysters are amazing.  Come here for these.  The oyster Shucker if you are nice to him, will let you take your photo with him.  (i'm not sure why we thought this such a novelty, perhaps it was caused by the hurricanes)come here for your oysters - go to Pat O'Briens for the hurricanes

Reviews.Author: Teneha B.
Reviews.Content: We had a 3 minute wait on the outside of the restaurant, as is customary.  The weather was nice, so this was not an issue.All staff members were courteous, from Larita the hostess to our server Sinny (cute name & face to match), even the bus boy (whose is unknown).  The atomsphere was busy yet not overwhelming.  The food was good to the taste and cost effective.This restaurant get a ++++ in my book.

Reviews.Author: Jason S.
Reviews.Content: Part of the perfect perfect New Orleans experience.I first came here when I was in college, I make it a point to always swing by when I'm in town, especially during in-between meals times - I've never had to wait and have sat up at the bar.Really, the best reason to come here is to get a bottle of local beer, have fresh oysters shucked for you and eat til you go blind.  Just add horseradish, catsup, tobasco, worchestershire and saltines.Kick back, eat and enjoy.

Reviews.Author: Sherri K.
Reviews.Content: "Stormin Norman" keepin' it real at the bar.Talk about oyster shuckin' madness.This place is probably one of the most talked about places to eat oysters while in New Orleans, but apparently, people should be talking about Stormin Norman who is world famous for his oyster shucking skills.The line was down the block , but lucky for me, a party of one or two can scoot right up to the front of the line if willing to sit at the oyster bar. I don't like to wait in line, so I would have sat on the curb to eat oysters that day.So fresh and so good!It's packed inside, and loud, but the energy is that of New York or any city where time is money and people love your food.2 words...Do IT!!

Reviews.Author: Nathan L.
Reviews.Content: I am a huge seafood fan and in particular oysters so it will come as no surprise that I am a really like Acme Oysters.  When we came here for lunch the line was out of the door but it really only took us about 30 minutes to eat.  It also helped that Dave went inside and got us all bloody Mary's while we waited.  When we finally got to our seat we knew exactly what we wanted.  Oysters.  12 Oysters for 14 dollars.  The oysters were huge.  I have never had oysters this big in my life and they were really good.  If youre a fan of oysters, this is a great place to get your fix.

Reviews.Author: Susan W.
Reviews.Content: I don't like oysters, but I love it here.Even if you're not a fish or oyster fan, you can still have a flavorful and fun dining experience at this New Orleans landmark.  On a recent visit we ordered one grilled sausage po boy, one fried shrimp po boy, a side of red beans and rice, and two Abita beers.  Perfection.Outstanding food, great value, and lots of fun rowdy atmosphere.

Reviews.Author: Eric H.
Reviews.Content: I was born and raise in New Orleans, yet never ate at the ACME, until I was a tourist, living away from the city for nearly 20 years. Why? Locals don't typically dine in the tourist areas of the French Quarter, prices are a little higher, parking is difficult, and there are plenty really good restaurants tucked away in neighborhoods throughout. That being said, since I was a tourist, staying in the Quarter, we made a point of grabbing lunch at the ACME. It's got a good reputation, and it's relatively inexpensive for  what you get. I got the Seafood etouffee, it was REALLY good, with lots of crawfish, shrimp, some fish and maybe some crabmeat. My wife ordered the chicken and sausage gumbo, really liked it, tasted authentic, wants to order it again. She also got Red Beans & Rice since it's the traditional Monday meal, good and creamy texture. We shared the deep fried crab claws, tasty & novel. We timed it so we didn't have to wait (2:30 pm).The rest rooms were extremely clean and well maintained, something you wouldn't expect at the Acme Oyster House. They do it right!

Reviews.Author: K G.
Reviews.Content: My perfect menu:1/2 dozen chargrilled oysters1/2 dozen crawpuppiesSide jambalayaSeafood étouffée (w/fried crawfish tails, natch)Abita Lights and keep 'em coming...and, commence. You'll wait in line, but it's worth it. You'll get in faster if you tell the guy at the door you will sit at the bar. Say hi to Hollywood at the oyster shucking bar for me...he's a New Orleans institution. One of my favorite restaurants on the planet and the only place I eat oysters.

Reviews.Author: Rita Y.
Reviews.Content: The place doesn't take reservations and everyday there's a long line outside for lunch and dinner.  I'm not certain it's worth all the hype. Maybe we ordered the wrong stuff or should've just stuck with raw oysters which Hubby doesn't like.  Not sure I'm ready to try raw oysters from the NOLA waters just yet with the oil spill history not too long ago.We tried:  Jambalaya, $10.99.  Hubby thought it was it was OK, I didn't really care for it.  My fried shrimp and oyster plate with fries wasn't anything special, $17.25.  The oysters were large but didn't have the sweet flavor that I'm used to from the SF Bay Area Tomales Bay oyster farm or Washington State oysters.  A glass of draft SamAdams was $4.  Not sure I'd make another trip back here if we're back to NOLA in the future.

Reviews.Author: Rachel H.
Reviews.Content: OMG! I was always told that eating raw oysters was gross, well I don't care anymore cause I just found the best way to eat them, chargrilled! My parents and my friends went here on a Saturday late afternoon, before the dinner rush and we were seated about 20 minutes later. It's not that bad of a wait. My Dad ordered the chargrilled oysters as an appetizer and after that he and I decided that a dozen was definitely not going to be enough. That topped with a pitcher of Abita Amber, again OMG cannot wait to go back home and go there again. Even if you don't like oysters you at least have to try one, they are cooked on an open flame, then topped with some awesome sauce and cheese. As the boyfriend says, everything is better with cheese.

Reviews.Author: John H.
Reviews.Content: Get the chard broiled oysters!!! Must haves!!

Reviews.Author: Haronyd M.
Reviews.Content: On our trip to New Orleans I really wanted to try every kind of food the Big Easy has to offer.  I'm not a fan of Oysters, so when this was recommended, I was apprehensive.  When you walk up to Acme Oyster House, you think you're going to a ride on Disney World as there is a huge line outside.  We were very fortunate that our wait was about 25 minutes and that we were seated at the Oyster Bar. The place was very crowded and lively and everyone from the guests to the bartenders was very friendly.  I wasn't sure what I wanted to drink since it was very early in the day, but the bartender prepared a his specialty for me... I still don't know what it was, all I know is that it had plenty of vodka.. No judging, I was on vacation!  The gentleman sitting next to us noticed we were a bit lost when it came to ordering oysters and suggested we get them Chargrilled.  We still felt unsure so we only ordered the "half platter."  As we waited we got to see how the Oysters are shucked.  The staff behind the bar was so attentive, it made the wait seem like only 5 minutes.  The Oysters arrived and WOW!!! They blew me away! They were absolutely delicious!! We even ordered a second platter.  I highly recommend this place to anyone visiting New Orleans.  I even got to go behind the bar and shuck an oyster myself!! Amazing!! Thanks Acme Oyster House!!

Reviews.Author: Dennis S.
Reviews.Content: DON'T go here for a meal - go for fresh oysters, beer, and atmosphere.If you're going to have a meal, it's a 3-star establishment.  Fine for a quick po' boy sandwich, but you're missing the point.  Acme Oyster Bar has been serving fresh shucked oyster at the bar for almost 100 years (100th anniversary in 2010!)  I was here the night before a Super Bowl in New Orleans and I was practically the only guy at the bar under 6'4" and without a Super Bowl ring on my finger.  This place is an institution, right around the corner as you walk to the French Quarter from Canal St.  Everybody elbows their way into the bar at Acme to partake of the giant pile of unopened oysters next to the bar.The guys behind the bar shuck your oysters when you order them and keep up an entertaining banter.  Guys or gals, no problem.  Just be ready to add the Tabasco sauce and horse radish to your seafood sauce, open a bag of Saltines, take a swig of your beer, and let those giant tender fresh oysters slide down your throat.  Your visit to the French Quarter doesn't get any better.

Reviews.Author: Noah C.
Reviews.Content: As much of a cliche as it was to eat here, it really was a good meal.We got everything stereotypical of New Orleans here - fresh, delicious oysters; perfectly acceptable jambalaya, gumbo and red beans and rice; tasty andouille sausage; and really good boiled crawfish.What made the night stand out, though, was skipping the line and heading to the bar. If you have a small group of people, this is the way to go - especially if you wind up with world-famous mother shucker Hollywood Broadway shucking your oysters for you. His humor, wit, and ability to talk to you about anything and everything makes for a really good time, and probably goes a long way to making those oysters taste even better. I'd come back just to hang out with him again.

Reviews.Author: Alan W.
Reviews.Content: As a New Orleans institution, what more needs to be said? I can only say that from the wealth of dining options available throughout town, after visiting the Acme Oyster House once, this was the only restaurant that my gf and I couldn't get out of our heads. We had an order of the raw oysters and one of the charbroiled oysters - I'm not even that into shellfish, but this made me want to steal some from my gf's share. =)Our solution? We came back for a second round right before we left for the airport. And it was absolutely worth it.

Reviews.Author: Alice L.
Reviews.Content: Love it, LOVE it, LOVE IT.  My dining experience goes like this: "Hi, what can I get for ya?""Umm...let's do a blue moon with a slice of orange. 1 dz fresh oysters, 1 dz chargrilled, and a cup of andouille gumbo. (turning to my dining partner) What do you want?"Yeah...sometimes we share that...lolI like to sit at the bar; the servers are always friendly and the other patrons are a hoot.  You're in NOLA, don't take life to seriously!  Have another beer, suck down those tasty fresh zinc filled miracles, and laugh your problems away.

Reviews.Author: Alice K.
Reviews.Content: Short & sweet:Service: 4Food: 4Wait time: 4*Price: 3Cleanliness of bathroom: 3I like seafood and I like shucked oysters. If I were not planning on buying a pair of Louboutins sometime in the (unfortunately, far-away) future, I would probably have eaten more. I don't know what I was thinking, but I grossly miscalculated how "full" I'd be after eating a plate of shucked oysters. I imagined myself to be somewhat full so I ordered a small cup of expensive gumbo. I finished my food and realized I was still starving, but had already spent a good amount of money. So then I ordered a muffuletta sandwich, which was too much food, and ate half of that.What I would do next time: Order only fresh seafood (the gumbo isn't worth it). After all, it's what Acme is renown for. Both raw and chargrilled oysters are delicious. The chargrilled comes with some butter cheese sauce melted over it and is accompanied by some bread pieces. A little salty but oh-so-good. Keep in mind that Acme is one of the most famous restaurants in NoLa. We went on a very ordinary Tuesday night and waited 15 minutes, but I hear the wait can be incredible. It's first come first serve so be prepared to wait on a weekend night. Also, it's a little pricier since it's seafood and since it's so famous. But the oysters...YUM!

Reviews.Author: Shannon S.
Reviews.Content: I've certainly noticed a decline over the years in the quality of the food here along with an increase in price (and the gumbo just doesn't seem worth ordering anymore to me).  Acme seems to have, unfortunately, earned the label of "tourist trap" for a reason but the oysters still seem to be consistently good and that should be the usual focus of a trip here.  The po boys or a fried seafood plate would also be a decent thing to sample in here.  The usual crazy lines at the French Quarter location make it a very rare thing that I will even attempt to eat oysters here as I hate lines but occasionally you can catch times without a line.  If there is a line I most often will be opting to eat raw oysters across the street at Felix's and I always prefer my grilled oysters at Drago's. If you've never been you probably should visit but to me it just usually isn't worth the wait or the cost.

Reviews.Author: Stephen T.
Reviews.Content: I stopped in here last night and grubbed, and boy was it amazing. There was a 20 minute wait outside at 7PM; but I made sure to tell the door guy that I would sit at the bar, so I got in quickly.First off - I think this place has the best bloody Mary's I have ever tasted. Seriously. Spicy, bloody, amazing. I had to have a second one.Second, the char-grilled oysters were some of the most delicious things EVER! I polished off a nice dozen of these before moving on to a half dozen raw. The sauce for the raw oysters is delicious; the perfect blend of sweet and spice.After consulting with the guy behind the bar, and my seatmate, I settled on the bread pudding for dessert. Delicious! Served with a nice bourbon and fruit sauce - the perfect end to an amazing meal.If you happen to be in NOLA at any point, consider this a "must do" and enjoy the char-grilled oysters.

Reviews.Author: Minda w.
Reviews.Content: Acme Oyster House was our first food stop of the trip. We were pretty excited and wanted to beat the crowds. Luckily, it was just a short 5 minute wait in line. We got a seat at the bar and ordered a 1/2 dozen chargrilled oysters and the peacemaker po boy.  I think we got our food faster than the time we had to wait in line. Chargrilled oysters: They were tasty but the tiniest oysters I've ever seen. The meat was more like a tiny clam than an oyster. Peacemaker Po Boy: More tiny shrimp and tiny oysters. Is it me or did I just think po boys are supposed to have big juicy fried oysters and shrimp? Loved the cocktail sauce, tarter sauce & mayo but that was about it. Acme Oyster House is definitely not worth the wait. If there is no line, it makes for an ok lunch.

Reviews.Author: Heather H.
Reviews.Content: Amazing. Amazing. Amazing!!You come to Acme for the experience of eating some dang tasty oysters, and if you're looking for the best seats, look no further than a spot at the bar. Acme's shuckers are the boss of whats good and will likely put a few extra oysters on your platter.  Benefits of being at the bar my friends! The oysters themselves are huge and full of salty flavor. I was plenty full after eating about 7 of them. The dining area is your typical divey bar and its always crowded which makes the place more fun in its chaos. If you can wait to stand in line for awhile, Acme is worth completing for an authentic New Orleans eating experience.

Reviews.Author: Valery C.
Reviews.Content: If a restaurant has a branch in the airport, you know its famous but that doesn't necessarily guarantee its good.  In any case, I figured nothing to lose popping into the French Quarter branch of this oyster institution when I didn't see a line in their queue outside to try some.  I got seated at the shucking bar on the right.  The restaurant itself is casual, divey, loud, and almost obnoxiously neon-lit, although underneath that, you can see some classic decor.Went with half dozen raw oysters on the half-shell and half dozen chargrilled oysters, which I haven't had before.  I got 7 of each (not sure how that works out to be a half-dozen).  The raw oysters were big and plump looking, accompanied by simple cocktail sauce and lemon wedges.  Although fresh and good texture, I was entirely unimpressed with the taste; I'm no oyster connoisseur but I've had my share of both West and East coast oysters in many places and these just lacked flavor of any kind, very bland.  The chargrilled oysters, on the other hand, were a surprise.  Topped with garlicky melted butter and cheese, they were cooked through but still juicy, a bit of smoky flavor, and enriched by the sauce.  Never had anything like it and really enjoyed that.  Another Abita (what else?), the amber, to wash down the oysters.Would skip the raw oysters, may not be a fan of Gulf oysters, but the chargrilled are worth having.

Reviews.Author: Pauline P.
Reviews.Content: Waited in an incredibly long line for oysters, but it was well worth it!// LOCATION // French Quarter, a few steps away from Bourbon Street// WAIT // Probably close to an hour for our party of 6. // FOOD //     +Raw oysters: Huge and so fresh! Can be ordered as a dozen or a half dozen. Served with line wedges and a tangy cocktail sauceGreat to experience once while in NOLA

Reviews.Author: Kristina O.
Reviews.Content: Don't like Oysters? Me either! Until I had them here. We had the Char grilled version with cheese. YUM! I would have eaten the entire dozen! I found a pearl in mine so if you are not slurping them be careful. You could chip a tooth! The red beans and rice pupa was huge and delicious. (a hollowed out french bread roll filled with red beans and rice and topped with grilled sausage) I am glad I got schooled on Oysters here and not anywhere else.

Reviews.Author: Faith X.
Reviews.Content: The chargrilled oysters here are absolutely INCREDIBLE. I can't recommend them more. I've been to Nola 3 times and have had to stop by Acme every time and every friend I've recommended Acme to has loooooved it. I can't even describe the oysters...it's just like heaven in your mouth. The wait can be really long, but the food is definitely worth the wait. If your time is flexible, try to go at the off hours (early or late dinner) to minimize your wait time. I've tried the gumbo and jambalaya here, which were just okay. I think you can find better places around for that. Come to Acme for the chargrilled oysters, and then eat lots of it.

Reviews.Author: Honest R.
Reviews.Content: We went on a Monday night and were told that the wait was 45 minutes for a table, but we only waited for about 20-25 minutes. We ordered the jambalaya and fried catfish were both excellent. The catfish had the perfect amount of batter, not too much, not too little. The waitress was super friendly. They do not split checks here.

Reviews.Author: David L.
Reviews.Content: We waited in a very long line before making our way into the restaurant. I literally got crapped on (by a bird) to grub here. I said to my party, "this place better be worth it." And indeed it was! The raw and charbroiled oysters were the best I've had during this trip. The seafood etouffee is an excellent choice as well. The service was prompt and attentive. By the time I was leaving this place, I had already forgotten about the whole bird poo incident.

Reviews.Author: Cyndi G.
Reviews.Content: They strongly recommend the charbroiled oysters and I have to agree, they were tasty.  Since that's the only thing we had besides the beer, I have to grudgingly give them 3 stars for the food.  Our service was dreadful and I strongly resent have a crafted beer served in the squishable plastic cups reserved for cheap keg parties.  I understand the lines because of the freshness of the oysters but I'd just as soon take the ride uptown to the Pearl district for Cooter Brown's.

Reviews.Author: Hannah S.
Reviews.Content: There's something tragic about a vegetarian in New Orleans ... especially given that it was only months ago I swore off seafood. Sigh.Visiting Acme Oyster House was a bit torturous, especially having to overlook the char-grilled oysters that sound so utterly amazing. My companion also raved about the fried shrimp po-boy. I'll give this place props for the veggie burger/po-boy option. At least there was something I could eat!I LOVE the atmosphere ... old, divey, totally charming. Neon lights and paraphernalia lined the walls. We had to wait outside, but for just a few moments.My veggie burger wasn't anything outstanding, but it was pretty tasty nonetheless. I also had a sweet little cocktail, quite lovely. So, take my review with a grain of salt. I have little doubt it would include extra stars had I been able to indulge in some seafood delights.

Reviews.Author: Shane S.
Reviews.Content: This place is a lot more commercialized since I came here decades ago! The piles of oysters in glass cases are gone.... the big black 200 lb " defensive line" looking guys are gone shucking in front of you. The "show" is sadly gone.... even when I tried to take a picture of the oysters on the grill the manager said " no pictures" ....what was this? a family secret that everyone serving oysters in NOLA has anyway? Anyone who knows a thing about raw oysters know oysters from this area are somewhat tasteless , fairly meaty and actually works best grilled. The character of the Acme Oyster house is what made it famous!! This place now looks more like a sports bar than a famous oyster shack. I love old school things..... some things should adapt with the times. Others like Acme Oyster house never should have changed !! Wish you could have seen it.......

Reviews.Author: Mimi J.
Reviews.Content: I'm going to be honest - the food was only really worth three stars but the ambiance was quite nice and the service was fabulous so they earned an extra star just for that.There seems to always be a huge line of people waiting to get into this place.  I discovered, however, that if you're there all by your lonesome, they'll move you right to the front of the line if you're willing to sit at the bar.  Let me see... stand outside in the smothering New Orleans heat and wait for a table or sit at the bar now in air conditioning...  Not exactly a hard choice.  There were television sets to watch and the bartender was very personable and helped me select a beer that I fell in love with (Turbodog).I ordered a platter which came with small amounts of New Orleans favorites gumbo, jambalaya, red beans & rice, and sausage.  The food was not bad, though both the red beans & rice and the jambalaya were bland and lacked seasoning.  The sausage was good but there wasn't much to it.  The best part was the atmosphere and the beer.  Next was the the seafood gumbo, but I just didn't get too excited by the food.The bread pudding was superb, though.I'm not sure if I'd come back or not, unless it's to try the oysters.  Maybe just for a late beer and dessert at the bar.

Reviews.Author: Timo Y.
Reviews.Content: Heard tons of good stuff bout this place. Got into NOLA from Milwaukee with my brother, hopped on a cab. checked in at the ritz. and we were in the line at ACME within 1 hour.Was surprised to see a line at 3.30pm but thought, oh well, screw it, i need my oyster fix bad! Waited in the line for not more than 10 minutes and a hostess came by asking the usual "how many, and asked bar or table" we were there just for oysters, so we said BAR! and got to skip past the erhh 10-15 people ahead of us and went straight in. Sat at the end and started talking to deborah (the bar manager) and Gab (our oyster shucker) and started the oyster marathon. Oysters: Great cold and fresh albeit a lil dirty ( i like slurping them from the shell, but in this instance i had to use the fork) They go through so many oysters a day that i understand if they can thoroughly wash the shells. But anyways those were great.(went later on the same night to felix's across the street and a dozen oysters are 10 bucks compared to 13 at ACME, i would say quality is the same and ACME is charging a premium because of how well known they are, I don't feel ripped off though, because it's still less than 1/2 of what i pay in the midwest for oysters)Chargrilled oysters: Awesome too. I asked Gab if they were good, his response was, "Are ya kidding me?! that's like the best thing on the menu!"(i later on find out that he doesn't eat oysters raw despite shucking a shitload(~2000) a day) The grilled oysters are coated with cheese and im guessing a light brush of butter. dip the french bread given with the juices and just slurp those up. Oh yeah, awesomeness, but at almost 20 bucks a dozen...erhhh i rather stick to eating my oysters raw. Just personally speaking, its great, but my goal is to get more oysters bang for my buck, so i would go the halfshell route, try the chargrilled ones, but just don't get too overfixated on it. Fried Crab Claws: Ordered this because we were still hungry after 4 dozen oysters. tasted great and i wish they had this in the midwest but dang it. We ARE LAND LOCKED!!(Lakes don't count in my books)All in all, great experience, We got a new foster mum (Deborah) in New Orleans who's gonna be checking on us to make sure we don't "get up to no good or drink too much" and we got recommendations to places around the area to check out from Deb and Gab so, go check them out. ALSO, 15 dozen oyster challenge, finish 15 dozen in an hour and you get 50% off the check. Go give it a shot!

Reviews.Author: Richard T.
Reviews.Content: First things first, I don't like oysters. However, I am a fan of Man Vs. Food so I normally try out places that he visits. New Orleans is the best food town in America, if not the world. You really can go wrong anywhere you eat but as in any big tourist cities, they have their own traps.  Im not saying this place was a trap but me being a non-oyster eater i found it to be the case. My coworker and I traveled to NOLA to eat and what we ordered at AOH was the Shrimp and oyster po boy, half dozen raw and the New Orleans medley. My favorite thing were the red beans and rice, everything else I had better elsewhere in NOLA. I love New Orleans after this first trip and I know i will be back for more.

Reviews.Author: Ann D.
Reviews.Content: I've been here so many times...I think it's time for a review!  Every time I come to NOLA it's a tradition to eat at Acme.  I've tried many things on the menu and everything is wonderful.  No matter where you sit, you can't complain about the service.  Everyone is very attentive and nice.  There's usually a line but the wait is worth it.  If you have to wait, go pick up a beer and drink while you wait in line.   If you want oysters this is the place to go.  I usually get a dozen raw oysters (FRESH), a dozen chargrilled oysters (AWESOME garlic melted butter and parmesan cheese grilled on the oysters),  BOO Fries (YUM...not sure if it's on the menu fries topped with their roast beef sauce and cheese), the Peace Maker Po Boy (DELISH...half fried oysters and half fried shrimp), cup of gumbo (GOOD...sometimes the rice is under done), and more ice cold beers.  Who doesn't love GO CUPS?!?!  Love NOLA...it's legal to drink on the streets!

Reviews.Author: Helen C.
Reviews.Content: I confess, I have something of an oyster obsession.  If you are what you eat, I became a giant vat of raw oysters the night I visited.  Let's just say the table next to me looked jealous/appalled at the amount of oysters I ordered -- and that was just for me, nevermind the amount that was sitting on the table to be shared by me and the old man.It may be sacrilege but I think Pascale's has better oysters, better shuckers and better prices on oysters. But that doesn't mean I don't have love for Acme even if that love is completely and utterly devoted to their amazing soft shell po' boy.  So delish, fried to perfection served on a perfectly warm, toasty roll.  Drooool.I also tried their gumbo, dirty rice and crawfish etouffe.  All very delicious but nothing came close to the po' boy.

Reviews.Author: Roy K.
Reviews.Content: Cold oysters were good but small....they can't be blamed for that. Chargrilled oysters aren't worth the money to me. $20 for a dozen and they are covered in things that don't make them taste like oysters...thus i can see why people like them but i actually like them raw and the flavor they have. Abita on draft for a decent priceenvironment is coolthey are about flipping tables due to the constant line...so the servers seem to lack the patience...which since it's a tourist place, thus new to most who walk through the door, it may feel a little pushy.

Reviews.Author: Lalaine C.
Reviews.Content: What is this "Acme Oyster Company", Wile E. Coyote's hangout while chasing the Roadrunner across NOLA?  All I heard and read was that Acme was the "it" place to have oysters.  But I've grown wary of hyped-up restaurants, since several places that Julius and I have been to lately have fallen short...just like Wile E.'s anvil drops. As soon as we approached Iberville Street, we saw the notorious long line in front of Acme.  Ahem, take me to the front!  I read on Yelp! that if you request to sit at the bar, there is no wait.  So I sauntered to the front of the line with an "I know something you don't know" 'tude only to be DENIED.  Attention, fellow Yelpers, even if you want to sit at the bar, you still have to wait in line (and I had a cute outfit on and I smiled at the guy too, so it wasn't that.)  Well, thank the voodoo gods for the French Quarter's open container law.  Having a plastic cup of chardonnay sure made the 30 minute wait a breeze!We were seated right at the oyster bar, which we HIGHLY recommend. You get a bird's eye view of guys shucking the oysters, and you get to chat it up with the super friendly staff behind the bar.  The people at Acme are just so welcoming and genuine, I didn't care that they ribbed us San Diegans for handing over our two star football players to the Saints (Brees and Sproles - hmmph!)  We asked our guy what he recommended from the menu, and he said without hesitation, the chargrilled oysters and the peacemaker po' boy (just like what I read on Yelp!)  So, did these two dishes live up to the hype?   You ain't whistlin' Dixie it did!The platter of chargrilled oysters were deliciously cheesy, garlicky, and buttery.  And the oysters were HUGE!  What are they feeding them here on the Gulf?  The peacemaker po' boy, a must-try sandwich of dueling fried oysters and shrimp, was my fave.  The seafood was light & non-greasy (how'd they do that?) and was so plentiful, it kept spilling over the airy French bread.  We also ordered a side of hush puppies - these yummy cornbread bites were sweet & filling, I skipped my requisite dessert! Acme Oyster Company was the perfect way to start off our vacation.  Don't get scared off by the lines, folks!  Just grab a beer to go, make friends with other tourists in line, and before you know it, you'll come face to face with the biggest and best oysters you'll ever have.

Reviews.Author: Nam T.
Reviews.Content: My first trip to NOLA and the first thing I did was walk 2 miles to Acme for lunch. It was just me, jet lagged, and a stomach ready to be pleased by what NOLA has to offer. I initially was just going to do the chargrilled and have a cup of jambalaya, but it turned into a gluttonous affair...and affair that I went back to the next day. My first visit, I got half a dozen chargrilled oysters and a cup of jambalaya. Decently price and it was good. While I was waiting I started talking to a nice lady from Kentucky and she asked me...politely "Why the hell aren't you eating the fresh oysters." To her I reply...."Hell why aren't I." So after finishing up the half dozen, I got a half dozen regular oysters for $12. Man those things are huge. I think a tear rolled down my face because I just realize how small oysters were where I'm from. The next day I just had to go back for some more. I was dreaming about them. I know there are other places. I'm on vacation so I figure I'm eating at least 5 more times in a day so I can do this again. I came back and this time I'm not fooling around. I got a dozen for $18 and I wolfed them down. I know the line here gets crazy but because it was just me, I got in no problem (lunch or dinner). Everyone tell me this place is where tourist go and for once I don't mind looking like a tourist. I love that it has this hole in the wall feeling since it's in an alley. So when people ask where should I eat if I'm in NOLA, I blurt out Acme.

Reviews.Author: Adam B.
Reviews.Content: Full disclosure here. I designed the Acme Oyster House website. In fact, I've been with Acme since 1999 and still am even though I relocated to Los Angeles post-Katrina.Enough said there. Still, I love Acme and not just because they're a great client (and they really are), but because they really provide great service and the food really is good overall. I'm not a Po-Boy person, so I won't go there but it is at the Lakefront location (now since relocated to Metry) where Acme taught me about the power of the Oyster Loaf. The Jambalaya is really one of the best in the area and the oysters? Well, c'mon! Gumbo Poopa is their answer to Chowder in a Sourdough Bread Bowl ala San Francisco and it's great. Anything bad? Well, I'm not huge into fried food and in the Quarter it dominates. Also, I wouldn't come here to get red beans. So many better places to do that in town. Desserts are great especially the Bananas Foster Pie.

Reviews.Author: Thomas L.
Reviews.Content: Raw Oysters ~ Raw Oysters, best I ever had. As far as the drinks go they have pitchers beer and mix drinks available. Anyway you want it, so we had it fried/grilled with cheese on top/ just raw with hot sauce.Pros: Reasonable price for oysters, try the platter and pitcher of blue moon.Cons: Gets packed badly, extremely long lines during weekend and evenings/dinner time.

Reviews.Author: Sean G.
Reviews.Content: Saw this place on Man vs. Food when Adam took the oyster challenge! We did have to wait to get in, but it was worth it. I have the soft shelled crab platter and the grilled oysters along with fried crawfish tails.  I reccomended this place for any tourist looking to get some good seafood. Make sure you order the bread pudding!!!!

Reviews.Author: Nosa E.
Reviews.Content: One of my favorite places to eat in nawlins! food is off the charts. I used to get the stuffed crab but the Peacemaker poboy changed my life. It should be called the pacemaker though cause with fried shrimp and oysters with tabasco mayo it aint the healthiest meal. But really who goes to New Orleans to be Healthy? Do yourself a favor and try the Boo Fries which is fries in brown gravy and melted cheese AND you have to have to have to get an order of the craw puppies...... its just like it sounds hush puppies batter mixed with this crawfish veggie medley. Its so dang good. over all i come here at least once when im in the crescent city and it never disappoints. IMPORTANT: There is usually a line so be smart and grab a drink a hurricane or beer (I avoid hand grenades) and enjoy your wait.

Reviews.Author: Ash B.
Reviews.Content: This place is a must! We've had oysters at a few different places in NoLA, and this is by far the best. The line is long, so prepare for a wait, especially during the weekends and dinner time. Luckily we went for an early dinner, late lunch, so we didn't wait that long.We ordered raw oysters and the charbroiled oysters. I'm more of a fan of raw oysters, and this was a first for the charbroiled, and my husband and I loved them. Out of all the places for the charbroiled oysters, this place is by far the best!!!Ordered the oyster rockerfeller soup. Delicious! It may be a little salty for some people, but we really enjoyed it.We enjoyed this place so much we even came back for an oyster dinner during our 3 day stay here!

Reviews.Author: Franco C.
Reviews.Content: Oysters!Beer!More Oysters!More bee-ah!Um, that about covers it.

Reviews.Author: Brian K.
Reviews.Content: I had to come back three times because it was so good! Actually, the food is decent and keep in mind, almost everything is fried and frying something (even if the batter is good) doesn't score too many points in my book. However, the food combined with the atmosphere provided for a really good time. This place is an excellent location (steps away from Bourbon) and the place has a really laid back feel to it. Everything is busy-busy so don't expect a quiet peaceful meal. You don't come to Acme Oyster House for that. Wow, full size oysters. I don't want to assume that they were wild oysters (they seemed farmed to me in terms of taste and from how the shells looked) but still, very good.  I was expecting dinky little things but it was a good size. One thing I did not like was that it was shucked beforehand. I'm sure the oyster turnover is very fast but still, it just sounds kind of bad that they were shucked prior to consumption.Can't really go wrong with any of their platters. The oyster platter comes with about six oysters, fries, and a side. The batter is great although they use too much of it. The shrimp is good to and the batter gives it a nice kick to it. Hush puppies. I've been living lies! All the hush puppies I've ever had before Acme was just not good compared to Acme's!  Super fresh and just tastes damn good. You need to order the red beans and rice, at least one order of it. No questions asked, just do it.

Reviews.Author: Debra L.
Reviews.Content: Acme is the most over-rated place in New Orleans. But, it's featured on all of the "best of" lists and Food Network specials so naturally everyone wants to go there. There are far better places to get oysters in New Orleans (like Felix's across the street or the new Drago's at the Riverwalk). But, Acme is fair. Raw oysters are plentiful and cheap and everything else is fried (oysters, shrimp, catfish, softshell crab, hushpuppies, french fries etc.) They also feature the traditional New Orleans fare that is so fun to pronounce (gumbo, jambalyaya, etouffe, and poopa). It's good for groups. It's no frills. It's not really worth waiting in line for but don't bother telling the folks you're with that. Let them figure it out for themseves - or not.

Reviews.Author: Fara A.
Reviews.Content: It's our 3rd day in N'Awlins and my husband keeps telling me we have to go back to get more oysters here. I don't eat oysters but I hope this gives you an idea of how delicious they are. My husband got them charbroiled and he is still dreaming about them.Anyhoo, I would've given this place 5 stars except I had a very mediocre po'boy (shrimp and catfish). The shrimp were tiny (almost bay sized)! and the catfish was just ok. I think Uncle Darrow's in LA is much, much better!

Reviews.Author: Gary B.
Reviews.Content: Was in town over the weekend. We tried to get in late on Friday but they said they were closing. No big deal...I will be back. Made it in on Sunday afternoon. Had a dozen raw and a dozen char-broiled and they were fantastic. Unfortunately I don't liver her because I think I would have oysters growing out of my ears!! Nice large place and reasonably priced. We enjoyed our food, beer and the Saints game on the big TV.

Reviews.Author: Sophia L.
Reviews.Content: It was my first day in NO, so I wanted to sample a little bit of everything...so I ordered the New Orleans medly. I would have to say I was disappointed in the portions of each item and totally didn't like the gumbo. My fiance's mother and father make better gumbo on the daily! Other than that the red beans and rice were good along with the jabalaya (my favorite on the plate) and the smoked sausage. I tried some fried shrimp and oysters from other plates on the table and was pleasantly surprised. Both were extremely well fried and full of flavor. The atmosphere is chill and laid back. I would definitely recommend coming here, especially if you like oysters.

Reviews.Author: Bret H.
Reviews.Content: Is it strange that this was our best overall dining experience in the city? We read about this place on Yelp. Great oysters, etc. etc. We walked over, and saw neon signs inside, heard loud music on the sound system, and figured it must be a tourist trap, some kind of South Coast Hard Rock Cafe. When our alternative turned out to be closed, we went back. Boy was that a good move.The oysters here are just incredible. I know oysters are oysters, but here they're briny-fresh from a local farm, shucked perfectly, and come with a spicy/tangy cocktail sauce that I wanted to eat by itself after the oysters were long gone. Toss in a light, crispy catfish sandwich, friendly, knowledgeable service, and I'm permanently sold.It was simple fare, but it was done so, so well, and it didn't cost a whole lot neither.

Reviews.Author: Dee M.
Reviews.Content: 10/29/09I arrived at around 1pm for lunch and there was a line, so of course I wondered if the wait would be worth it.  The hostess seated me after 5 minutes - hooray.  I must say I've never dined at a restaurant where you have to wait to be seated at a bar.  So, don't expect to walk passed that line of people thinking you'll just sit at the bar.  You will quickly get your feelings hurt.  I witnessed this first hand several times while sitting at the bar.  The food was actually very good.  I ordered the half and half po boy with catfish and shrimp - delicious!  The soft shell po boy looked extremely good as well.  Had the hush puppies as a side dish since the po boy does not include one.  They were also very good.  Including my Sierra Mist, my total bill came to $15.07 before tip.  Not bad.The service was quite humorous.  The bartender/oyster clucker conversed with me the entire time about how he has no rules, no woman, and won't travel anywhere where he can't drink outside on public streets.  As he slid me the check, he mentioned that his number was on the receipt, that I could call him anytime, and to consider that he may just want to move out to San Diego.  Hilarious!Acme is a must for good food and good times.

Reviews.Author: Holly C.
Reviews.Content: We got there at 10:55 AM & were the first ones there. By the time we were seated at 11:10 AM - there was a long line! The place filled up within a matter of a few minutes!For our appetizer, we ordered a dozen charboiled oysters. They cook them with some kind of cheese & it was delicious! The bread came in handy. We used it to soak up all the sauce!For my entree, I ordered the Fried Peacemaker Po' Boy (fried shrimp & oyster with tobasco infused mayo). I was intrigued how the po' boys were made with a different kind of bread. The hot sauce gave it a great touch. Because it's all fried food (and I usually eat pretty healthy), I felt very heavy. But heck with it, it was worth it!

Reviews.Author: Lauryn C.
Reviews.Content: This was hands down one of the best places I ate when I was visiting NOLA.  It's casual the people are over the top friendly and the drinks are tasty and at the right price.With so many choices we just decided to order a bunch of different items on the menu and share.  The po-boy with shrimp & oysters was the best po-boy I had while I was in NOLA  - big plus they cut it in 4 sections for our party.  The charbroiled oysters I regret even trying them in any other restaurant after having them at ACME they were unbelievable I could have eaten 3 dozen myself.  Fried crab claws YES YES YES!.  Theonly food that really didn't wow me was the etouffee.  ACME I will be back soon!

Reviews.Author: Cristy C.
Reviews.Content: Love their oysters. Who doesn't?! I think this review is completely unnecessary because you pretty much have 790 other people telling you the same damn thing. Don't be a pussy. TRY THEM. I know they don't look all that appetizing to some, but they are DELICIOUS! You will regret not trying them if you're visiting. The oyster guilt will haunt you until you return.

Reviews.Author: Eileen K.
Reviews.Content: This was our first food stop in NOLA. I was hesitant to go because I'd heard that its booming with tourists and that the wait is ridiculous..but well...we WERE tourists...and gotta try the place we've heard most about right?! We were ready to brave the line!And yes, the line was indeed long, but went suprisingly fast. We had a group of 10+ people, and got seated within 20-30 minutes. (with the excitement of being in NOLA and taking pictures and chit chatting, time flew by!) The goods:-Bustling, vibrant environment in the heart of French Quarter, a block from Bourbon st. A great way to start off our first night and get us pumped up!-Their Hurricanes, though pricey, were delicious!-New Orleans Medley: jambalaya, sausage, gumbo, red beans and rice. A perfect tour and preview of the foods to come!! (I especially enjoyed their jambalaya..so full of flavor!!)-Their Chargrilled oysters were delicious!! chockfull of flavor!! and so juicy! (as were their raw oysters) The bad:-Oysters were really small in comparison to other places i visited that weekend. (Luke's *cough* happy hour!!) I'm glad we decided to go. It was a great way to start off our NOLA week, and a delicious preview of the foods to come. Warning is that it is a bit pricey. (once again...Luke's happy hour!! *cough*)

Reviews.Author: Jennifer C.
Reviews.Content: You MUST get the boo fries. Their roast beef gravy is one of the tastiest I've EVER had ... and I pride myself on being a french fries with cheese/gravy (aka: disco fries) connoisseur. My boyfriend got the oyster shooters which looked awesome although I can't say I sampled. He enjoyed them.We shared a fried shrimp platter with hush puppies and the trio that included gumbo, jambalaya, rice/beans and a smoked sausage link. Everything was very flavorful. The gumbo really stood out for me.Decent prices, nice menu, friendly staff. There's always a line, but it's definitely worth the wait. A must try!!!

Reviews.Author: Jinhoo J.
Reviews.Content: I feel like this way was too overrated. I guess my expectations were too high after seeing the long line of people the night before. We ordered the char-grilled oysters and fried soft shell crab with sweet potato fries and potato salad. The famous char-grilled oysters were good but unfortunately I thought the ones I had at Felix's across the street were a tad better. The sweet potato fries and potato salad were good, but you can get good fries and salad anywhere. The soft-shell crab was just meh.. The batter was too salty and the crab was tiny. Service was just okay. For all that hype about this place, I was disappointed.

Reviews.Author: Matt M.
Reviews.Content: Outstanding all around. Got immediately seated at the bar so no wait.  Soup of the day was Lima bean and andouille sausage.   Reminded me of my mom's lb soup so definitely good. Do what most reviews suggest and get the chargrilled oysters.  Buttery and not heart healthy but if it's vacation then why not. Hostess was great and service was above board.

Reviews.Author: Tehmin L.
Reviews.Content: a lot of hype to this place and was a good but not worth a 45 min wait.  There are tons of other places to eat, but this place is iconic so you have to go at least once.pros - - bread pudding was freaking good- decent selection of beer on tap- I didn't realize this, but their oyster shooters are in shots of vodka.  I thought they came in shot glasses with some sauce.  Ordered 3 of them, ended only shooting 1cons - - beer in cups..not my thing.  I like my beer in ice cold glasses.  I get it's the whole bar hop thing, but at least give me the option to have glass- place was small and dark...kind of divey

Reviews.Author: Drew S.
Reviews.Content: I'm not sure why both sides of my family keep insisting on going here.  Sure it's an old school place to get fresh shucked oysters but there's also always a giant line of people from out of town with fanny packs and track suits.  Not the restaurants fault but I worked next door for two years and had to fight through the crowd to get to work everyday.  A little dirty on the inside but the charbroiled oysters are big time addictive.

Reviews.Author: Mai S.
Reviews.Content: Yes, it's touristy.  Yes, you have to wait in line.  Yes, it's totally worth it.  Of course, if you don't like raw oysters, then you might not enjoy it quite as much... but you can still watch everyone else slurp down those oysters.I'm used to the ridiculously high prices of oysters in SF Bay Area, so a dozen raws for $11?!!  What a steal!  We started off with 2 dozen raws, and 1/2 dozen of the chargrilled.  The raws went fast, and the chargrilled went even faster.  Omg, they are delicious!!  I don't really liked cooked oysters, but the chargrilled are amazingly good covered in butter and cheese.We also had the fried catfish, fried softshell crab, gumbo and boiled crawfish.  The catfish was one of my fav dishes, and I couldn't stop eating it!  The batter was so light and crisp, and the fish was flavorful and light.  The softshell crab was good also, and the gumbo was probably the least impressive.  The boiled crawfish was delicious, but a little too much work for such a small amount of meat!As if we didn't order enough food already, we had to order a couple dozen more of the raws and chargrilled!  Seriously, the chargrilled oysters are so good.  I would go back there again just for that.

Reviews.Author: Courtney M.
Reviews.Content: I was told by my family while we were in New Orleans for Thanksgiving that we HAD to eat at Acme Oyster House, no matter what. So on Friday night we decided to head there for dinner. Now, I'm not a big oyster fan but they assured me that charbroiled these little balls of slime are the best thing ever. We got there and saw a huge line out the door. It was cold, 40something degrees and I was not dressed for the weather. My husband and I pointed out all sorts of nearby places that didn't have a line but they were adamant, it was Acme or bust. So we waited for about 45 minutes while I plotted grabbing a trash can and starting a fire to un-numb my hands. We were finally seated and ordered two dozen charbroiled oysters for an appetizer for the table.  They were good, don't get me wrong. On bread with a bit of the green Tabasco sauce? I actually enjoyed oysters for the first time in my life. Now, were they worth freezing my butt off for 45 minutes? Hell no. I followed them up with the New Orleans Medley platter which contained red beans and rice, gumbo, jambalaya, and sausage. It was all very tasty (the jambalaya especially so) and the bread pudding desert was rich and delicious. If you're a huge oyster person, I recommend giving Acme a shot. But if you're like me and really aren't a fan and the weather isn't great I say skip the line and head somewhere else.

Reviews.Author: Jamison U.
Reviews.Content: Really an dangerous place for  bivalve molluscs (specifically those of brackish habituation) as I have been known to consume them 3 or 4 dozen at a time. To be sure ACME is a great place for all your food needs (Gubo, Red Beans, and all that).I know its a tourist trap, and such but seriously. Get here early and often.

Reviews.Author: Danielle S.
Reviews.Content: Good place in the Quarter for fresh oysters, a little gumbo, maybe some crawfish etouffee if you still have room and a few Abita's.Always packed, you may have to wait, but worth it.

Reviews.Author: Shirley N.
Reviews.Content: 4.0 oysters3.0 seafood gumbo and jambalaya We came for dinner around 5:30pm to avoid waiting in a long line.  Choice of sitting at a table or at the counter.  Went with a table.Seafood gumbo - shrimp but no crabmeat found.Jambalaya - sausage but no chicken found.Hush puppies - tiny cornmeal balls.  Ok.Fresh oysters.   1/2 doz raw and 1/2 doz charbroiled.  We prefer them raw.  But both styles were excellent.   Banana Foster dessert is actually a slice of cheesecake.  We enjoyed it with a cup of coffee.This place was good but very overrated and overhyped.  I definitely would not wait in line to eat here.

Reviews.Author: Alan Q.
Reviews.Content: You know when there is a line outside (approximately 20 people long), the place has to be good. We stumbled onto this place after one of my friends from CA read the reviews. She is a seafood person and really loves oysters and crawfish. While waiting outside, the waiters would come out and ask if anyone wants to sit at the bar. Seeing how it's all the same, and you get the same services, if not more attention, we decided to skip the line and head to the bar. Upon sitting down, we looked at the menu's and noticed the prices of the oysters. Just to be clear, I do not eat oysters, so I would know nothing about them. My friend on the other hand, she's an oyster maniac. She gushed about the prices of the oysters and how affordable (and reasonably cheap compared to CA). We ordered a dozen Fresh, Ice Cold oysters and half a dozen Chargrilled Oysters. We also ordered the New Orleans Medley and the Acme "10 Napkin Roast Beef" po-boy sandwich. Once again, to emphasize, I do not eat oysters. When the dozen raw cold, gray, weird looking, yet fresh (described by my friend) came out, I did not want to touch it. Therefore I can not comment on that. But in the words of my friend, "They were DELICIOUS!" She said she would recommend them for all the oysters eaters out there. The Chargrilled Oysters on the other hand, that I could eat. I tried one of them, and they were DELICIOUS as well. This coming from one who does not eat oysters.
